column2: RINKITINK IN OZ Wherein is recorded the Perilous Quest of Prince Inga of Pingaree and King Rinkitink in the Magical Isles that lie beyond the Borderland of Oz.
column3: RINKITINK IN OZ Wherein is recorded the Perilous Quest of Prince Inga of Pingaree and King Rinkitink in the Magical Isles that lie beyond the Borderland of Oz.

column2: By L Frank Baum Royal Historian of Oz.
column3: By L Frank Baum Royal Historian of Oz.

column2: Introducing this Story.
column3: Introducing this Story.

column2: Here is a story with a boy hero, and a boy of whom you have never before heard. There are girls in the story, too, including our old friend Dorothy,
column3: Here is a story with a boy hero, and a boy of whom you have never before heard. There are girls in the story, too, including our old friend Dorothy,

column2: and some of the characters wander a good way from the Land of Oz before they all assemble in the Emerald City to take part in Ozma's banquet.
column3: and some of the characters wander a good way from the Land of Oz before they all assemble in the Emerald City to take part in Ozma's banquet.

column2: Indeed, I think you will find this story quite different from the other histories of Oz, but I hope you will not like it the less on that account.
column3: Indeed, I think you will find this story quite different from the other histories of Oz, but I hope you will not like it the less on that account.

column2: If I am permitted to write another Oz book it will tell of some thrilling adventures encountered by Dorothy, Betsy Bobbin, Trot and the Patchwork Girl right in the Land of Oz,
column3: If I am permitted to write another Oz book it will tell of some thrilling adventures encountered by Dorothy, Betsy Bobbin, Trot and the Patchwork Girl right in the Land of Oz,

column2: and how they discovered some amazing creatures that never could have existed outside a fairy land.
column3: and how they discovered some amazing creatures that never could have existed outside a fairy land.

column2: I have an idea that about the time you are reading this story of Rinkitink I shall be writing that story of Adventures in Oz.
column3: I have an idea that about the time you are reading this story of Rinkitink I shall be writing that story of Adventures in Oz.

column2: Don't fail to write me often and give me your advice and suggestions, which I always appreciate.
column3: Don't fail to write me often and give me your advice and suggestions, which I always appreciate.

column2: I get a good many letters from my readers, but every one is a joy to me and I answer them as soon as I can find time to do so.
column3: I get a good many letters from my readers, but every one is a joy to me and I answer them as soon as I can find time to do so.

column2: If you have a map of the Land of Oz handy, you will find that the great Nonestic Ocean washes the shores of the Kingdom of Rinkitink,
column3: If you have a map of the Land of Oz handy, you will find that the great Nonestic Ocean washes the shores of the Kingdom of Rinkitink,

column2: between which and the Land of Oz lies a strip of the country of the Nome King and a Sandy Desert.
column3: between which and the Land of Oz lies a strip of the country of the Nome King and a Sandy Desert.

column2: The Kingdom of Rinkitink isn't very big and lies close to the ocean, all the houses and the King's palace being built near the shore.
column3: The Kingdom of Rinkitink isn't very big and lies close to the ocean, all the houses and the King's palace being built near the shore.

column2: The people live much upon the water, boating and fishing, and the wealth of Rinkitink is gained from trading along the coast and with the islands nearest it.
column3: The people live much upon the water, boating and fishing, and the wealth of Rinkitink is gained from trading along the coast and with the islands nearest it.

column2: Four days' journey by boat to the north of Rinkitink is the Island of Pingaree, and as our story begins here I must tell you something about this island.
column3: Four days' journey by boat to the north of Rinkitink is the Island of Pingaree, and as our story begins here I must tell you something about this island.

column2: At the north end of Pingaree, where it is widest, the land is a mile from shore to shore, but at the south end it is scarcely half a mile broad;
column3: At the north end of Pingaree, where it is widest, the land is a mile from shore to shore, but at the south end it is scarcely half a mile broad;

column2: thus, although Pingaree is four miles long, from north to south, it cannot be called a very big island.
column3: thus, although Pingaree is four miles long, from north to south, it cannot be called a very big island.

column2: It is exceedingly pretty, however, and to the gulls who approach it from the sea it must resemble a huge green wedge lying upon the waters, for its grass and trees give it the color of an emerald.
column3: It is exceedingly pretty, however, and to the gulls who approach it from the sea it must resemble a huge green wedge lying upon the waters, for its grass and trees give it the color of an emerald.

column2: The grass came to the edge of the sloping shores; the beautiful trees occupied all the central portion of Pingaree,
column3: The grass came to the edge of the sloping shores; the beautiful trees occupied all the central portion of Pingaree,

column2: forming a continuous grove where the branches met high overhead and there was just space beneath them for the cosy houses of the inhabitants.
column3: forming a continuous grove where the branches met high overhead and there was just space beneath them for the cosy houses of the inhabitants.

column2: These houses were scattered everywhere throughout the island, so that there was no town or city, unless the whole island might be called a city.
column3: These houses were scattered everywhere throughout the island, so that there was no town or city, unless the whole island might be called a city.

column2: The canopy of leaves, high overhead, formed a shelter from sun and rain, and the dwellers in the grove could all look past the straight tree trunks and across the grassy slopes to the purple waters of the Nonestic Ocean.

column2: At the big end of the island, at the north, stood the royal palace of King Kitticut, the lord and ruler of Pingaree. It was a beautiful palace,
column3: At the big end of the island, at the north, stood the royal palace of King Kitticut, the lord and ruler of Pingaree. It was a beautiful palace,

column2: built entirely of snow white marble and capped by domes of burnished gold, for the King was exceedingly wealthy.
column3: built entirely of snow white marble and capped by domes of burnished gold, for the King was exceedingly wealthy.

column2: All along the coast of Pingaree were found the largest and finest pearls in the whole world.
column3: All along the coast of Pingaree were found the largest and finest pearls in the whole world.

column2: These pearls grew within the shells of big oysters, and the people raked the oysters from their watery beds, sought out the milky pearls and carried them dutifully to their King.
column3: These pearls grew within the shells of big oysters, and the people raked the oysters from their watery beds, sought out the milky pearls and carried them dutifully to their King.

column2: Therefore, once every year His Majesty was able to send six of his boats, with sixty rowers and many sacks of the valuable pearls, to the Kingdom of Rinkitink,
column3: Therefore, once every year His Majesty was able to send six of his boats, with sixty rowers and many sacks of the valuable pearls, to the Kingdom of Rinkitink,

column2: where there was a city called Gilgad, in which King Rinkitink's palace stood on a rocky headland and served, with its high towers, as a lighthouse to guide sailors to the harbor.
column3: where there was a city called Gilgad, in which King Rinkitink's palace stood on a rocky headland and served, with its high towers, as a lighthouse to guide sailors to the harbor.

column3: and the boats went back to the island laden with stores of rich merchandise and such supplies of food as the people and the royal family of Pingaree needed.

column2: The Pingaree people never visited any other land but that of Rinkitink, and so there were few other lands that knew there was such an island.
column3: The Pingaree people never visited any other land but that of Rinkitink, and so there were few other lands that knew there was such an island.

column2: it was said were twin islands named Regos and Coregos, inhabited by a fierce and warlike people.
column3: it was said were twin islands named Regos and Coregos, inhabited by a fierce and warlike people.

column2: Many years before this story really begins, ten big boatloads of those fierce warriors of Regos and Coregos visited Pingaree, landing suddenly upon the north end of the island.
column3: Many years before this story really begins, ten big boatloads of those fierce warriors of Regos and Coregos visited Pingaree, landing suddenly upon the north end of the island.

column3: This defeat of the enemy seemed the more wonderful because the pearl fishers of Pingaree were mild and peaceful in disposition and seldom quarreled even among themselves.

column2: Their only weapons were their oyster rakes; yet the fact remains that they drove their fierce enemies from Regos and Coregos from their shores.

column3: This anxiety on the part of King Kitticut led him to keep a sharp lookout for strange boats, one of his men patrolling the beach constantly, but he was too wise to allow any fear to make him or his subjects unhappy.

column3: He was a good King and lived very contentedly in his fine palace, with his fair Queen Garee and their one child, Prince Inga.

column2: The wealth of Pingaree increased year by year; and the happiness of the people increased, too. Perhaps there was no place, outside the Land of Oz,
column3: The wealth of Pingaree increased year by year; and the happiness of the people increased, too. Perhaps there was no place, outside the Land of Oz,

column2: Prince Inga, the heir to all the riches and the kingship of Pingaree, grew up surrounded by every luxury; but he was a manly little fellow, although somewhat too grave and thoughtful,
column3: Prince Inga, the heir to all the riches and the kingship of Pingaree, grew up surrounded by every luxury; but he was a manly little fellow, although somewhat too grave and thoughtful,

column2: and he could never bear to be idle a single minute.
column3: and he could never bear to be idle a single minute.

column2: He knew where the finest oysters lay hidden along the coast and was as successful in finding pearls as any of the men of the island, although he was so slight and small.
column3: He knew where the finest oysters lay hidden along the coast and was as successful in finding pearls as any of the men of the island, although he was so slight and small.

column2: He had a little boat of his own and a rake for dragging up the oysters and he was very proud indeed when he could carry a big white pearl to his father.
column3: He had a little boat of his own and a rake for dragging up the oysters and he was very proud indeed when he could carry a big white pearl to his father.

column2: There was no school upon the island, as the people of Pingaree were far removed from the state of civilization that gives our modern children such advantages as schools and learned professors,
column3: There was no school upon the island, as the people of Pingaree were far removed from the state of civilization that gives our modern children such advantages as schools and learned professors,

column3: Being a man of intelligence, he was able to teach his son something of reading, writing and arithmetic.

column2: King Kitticut was very proud of his little son, as well he might be,
column3: King Kitticut was very proud of his little son, as well he might be,

column3: and he soon felt a high respect for Inga's judgment and thought that he was worthy to be taken into the confidence of his father in many matters of state.

column2: He taught the boy the needs of the people and how to rule them justly, for some day he knew that Inga would be King in his place.
column3: He taught the boy the needs of the people and how to rule them justly, for some day he knew that Inga would be King in his place.

column2: One day he called his son to his side and said to him: Our island now seems peaceful enough, Inga, and we are happy and prosperous, but I cannot forget those terrible people of Regos and Coregos.
column3: One day he called his son to his side and said to him: Our island now seems peaceful enough, Inga, and we are happy and prosperous, but I cannot forget those terrible people of Regos and Coregos.

column2: My constant fear is that they will send a fleet of boats to search for those of their race whom we defeated many years ago, and whom the sea afterwards destroyed.
column3: My constant fear is that they will send a fleet of boats to search for those of their race whom we defeated many years ago, and whom the sea afterwards destroyed.

column2: If the warriors come in great numbers we may be unable to oppose them, for my people are little trained to fighting at best; they surely would cause us much injury and suffering.
column3: If the warriors come in great numbers we may be unable to oppose them, for my people are little trained to fighting at best; they surely would cause us much injury and suffering.

column2: Are we, then, less powerful than in my grandfather's day? asked Prince Inga.
column3: Are we, then, less powerful than in my grandfather's day? asked Prince Inga.

column2: It is not that, said he. That you may fully understand that marvelous battle, I must confide to, you a great secret. I have in my possession three Magic Talismans,
column3: It is not that, said he. That you may fully understand that marvelous battle, I must confide to, you a great secret. I have in my possession three Magic Talismans,

column3: He led the way through the rooms of the palace until they came to the great banquet hall. There, stopping in the center of the room, he stooped down and touched a hidden spring in the tiled floor.

column2: At once one of the tiles sank downward and the King reached within the cavity and drew out a silken bag.
column3: At once one of the tiles sank downward and the King reached within the cavity and drew out a silken bag.

column2: This bag he proceeded to open, showing Inga that it contained three great pearls, each one as big around as a marble. One had a blue tint and one was of a delicate rose color,
column3: This bag he proceeded to open, showing Inga that it contained three great pearls, each one as big around as a marble. One had a blue tint and one was of a delicate rose color,

column2: but the third was pure white.

column2: These three pearls, said the King, speaking in a solemn, impressive voice, are the most wonderful the world has ever known.
column3: These three pearls, said the King, speaking in a solemn, impressive voice, are the most wonderful the world has ever known.

column2: They were gifts to one of my ancestors from the Mermaid Queen, a powerful fairy whom he once had the good fortune to rescue from her enemies.
column3: They were gifts to one of my ancestors from the Mermaid Queen, a powerful fairy whom he once had the good fortune to rescue from her enemies.

column2: In gratitude for this favor she presented him with these pearls. Each of the three possesses an astonishing power, and whoever is their owner may count himself a fortunate man.
column3: In gratitude for this favor she presented him with these pearls. Each of the three possesses an astonishing power, and whoever is their owner may count himself a fortunate man.

column2: This one having the blue tint will give to the person who carries it a strength so great that no power can resist him. The one with the pink glow will protect its owner from all dangers that may threaten him,

column2: What is this, my father! exclaimed the Prince, amazed; do you tell me that a pearl can speak? It sounds impossible.
column3: What is this, my father! exclaimed the Prince, amazed; do you tell me that a pearl can speak? It sounds impossible.

column2: Your doubt is due to your ignorance of fairy powers, returned the King, gravely. Listen, my son, and you will know that I speak the truth.
column3: Your doubt is due to your ignorance of fairy powers, returned the King, gravely. Listen, my son, and you will know that I speak the truth.

column2: The powers of the other pearls are even greater, resumed the King.

column2: Were I poor in all else, these gems would make me richer than any other monarch the world holds.

column3: The powers are mine only while I have the pearls upon my person, answered King Kitticut, and I dare not carry them constantly for fear they might be lost.

column2: The prow of the boat grounded on the beach, stopping its speed so suddenly that the little man was caught unawares and nearly toppled headlong into the sea.
column3: The prow of the boat grounded on the beach, stopping its speed so suddenly that the little man was caught unawares and nearly toppled headlong into the sea.

column2: But he managed to catch hold of the chair with one hand and the hair of one of his rowers with the other, and so steadied himself.
column3: But he managed to catch hold of the chair with one hand and the hair of one of his rowers with the other, and so steadied himself.

column2: Then, again waving his jeweled cap around his head, he cried in a merry voice: Well, here I am at last!

column2: So I perceive, responded King Kitticut, bowing with much dignity.

column3: The fat man glanced at all the sober faces before him and burst into a rollicking laugh. Perhaps I should say it was half laughter and half a chuckle of merriment,

column2: Keek eek eek eek! This is funny it's really funny. Didn't know I was coming, did you? Hoo, hoo, hoo, hoo! This is certainly amusing. But I'm here, just the same.

column2: Hush up! said a deep, growling voice. You're making yourself ridiculous.

column2: The rowers of the boat were all solemn and silent and certainly no one on the shore had spoken.

column2: King Kitticut now addressed the stranger, saying courteously: You are welcome to the Kingdom of Pingaree.
column3: King Kitticut now addressed the stranger, saying courteously: You are welcome to the Kingdom of Pingaree.

column2: Perhaps you will deign to come ashore and at your convenience inform us whom we have the honor of receiving as a guest.
column3: Perhaps you will deign to come ashore and at your convenience inform us whom we have the honor of receiving as a guest.

column2: Thanks; I will, returned the little fat man, waddling from his place in the boat and stepping, with some difficulty, upon the sandy beach.
column3: Thanks; I will, returned the little fat man, waddling from his place in the boat and stepping, with some difficulty, upon the sandy beach.

column2: I am King Rinkitink, of the City of Gilgad in the Kingdom of Rinkitink, and I have come to Pingaree to see for myself the monarch who sends to my city so many beautiful pearls.
column3: I am King Rinkitink, of the City of Gilgad in the Kingdom of Rinkitink, and I have come to Pingaree to see for myself the monarch who sends to my city so many beautiful pearls.

column2: I have long wished to visit this island; and so, as I said before, here I am!
column3: I have long wished to visit this island; and so, as I said before, here I am!

column2: I am pleased to welcome you, said King Kitticut. But why has Your Majesty so few attendants?
column3: I am pleased to welcome you, said King Kitticut. But why has Your Majesty so few attendants?

column2: Is it not dangerous for the King of a great country to make distant journeys in one frail boat, and with but twenty men?
column3: Is it not dangerous for the King of a great country to make distant journeys in one frail boat, and with but twenty men?

column2: Oh, I suppose so, answered King Rinkitink, with a laugh. But what else could I do? My subjects would not allow me to go anywhere at all, if they knew it. So I just ran away.
column3: Oh, I suppose so, answered King Rinkitink, with a laugh. But what else could I do? My subjects would not allow me to go anywhere at all, if they knew it. So I just ran away.

column2: Ran away! exclaimed King Kitticut in surprise.
column3: Ran away! exclaimed King Kitticut in surprise.

column2: Funny, isn't it? Heh, heh, heh woo, hoo! laughed Rinkitink, and this is as near as I can spell with letters the jolly sounds of his laughter.
column3: Funny, isn't it? Heh, heh, heh woo, hoo! laughed Rinkitink, and this is as near as I can spell with letters the jolly sounds of his laughter.

column2: Fancy a King running away from his own ple hoo, hoo keek, eek, eek, eek! But I had to, don't you see!

column2: They're afraid I'll get into mischief. They don't trust me.

column2: Keek eek eek Oh, dear me! Don't trust their own King. Funny, isn't it?

column2: No harm can come to you on this island, said Kitticut, pretending not to notice the odd ways of his guest. And, whenever it pleases you to return to your own country,

column3: Much obliged, answered Rinkitink, tipping his white cap over his left ear and heartily shaking the hand of his brother monarch.

column3: And, by the way, continued the fat little King, let them also take my goat from his cage.

column3: But I'm too fat. Really, Bilbil, I'm surprised at you. Haven't I brought you all this distance so you may see something of the world and enjoy life?

column3: And now you are so ungrateful as to refuse to carry me!

column2: ' Will they not miss Your Majesty from your palace at Gilgad? inquired Kitticut.

column2: ' How's that, eh? Fine thought, what? 'Therefore, in order to be Good, you must avoid those Things which are Evil.' Oh, hoo hoo hoo! how clever!
column3: ' How's that, eh? Fine thought, what? 'Therefore, in order to be Good, you must avoid those Things which are Evil.' Oh, hoo hoo hoo! how clever!

column2: Now that the King, his father, was so much occupied with his royal guest, Inga was often left to amuse himself, for a boy could not be allowed to take part in the conversation of two great monarchs.
column3: Now that the King, his father, was so much occupied with his royal guest, Inga was often left to amuse himself, for a boy could not be allowed to take part in the conversation of two great monarchs.

column2: He devoted himself to his studies, therefore, and day after day he climbed into the branches of his favorite tree and sat for hours in his tree top rest,

column2: reading his father's precious manuscripts and thinking upon what he read.

column2: You must not think that Inga was a molly coddle or a prig, because he was so solemn and studious. Being a King's son and heir to a throne, he could not play with the other boys of Pingaree,

column3: and he lived so much in the society of the King and Queen, and was so surrounded by the pomp and dignity of a court, that he missed all the jolly times that boys usually have.

column2: and more grave and thoughtful than one of his years should be.

column2: Inga was in his tree one morning when, without warning, a great fog enveloped the Island of Pingaree. The boy could scarcely see the tree next to that in which he sat,
column3: Inga was in his tree one morning when, without warning, a great fog enveloped the Island of Pingaree. The boy could scarcely see the tree next to that in which he sat,

column3: but the leaves above him prevented the dampness from wetting him, so he curled himself up in his seat and fell fast asleep.

column2: All that forenoon the fog continued. King Kitticut, who sat in his palace talking with his merry visitor, ordered the candles lighted, that they might be able to see one another.

column3: The good Queen, Inga's mother, found it was too dark to work at her embroidery, so she called her maidens together and told them wonderful stories of bygone days,

column2: in order to pass away the dreary hours.
column3: in order to pass away the dreary hours.

column2: But soon after noon the weather changed. The dense fog rolled away like a heavy cloud and suddenly the sun shot his bright rays over the island.
column3: But soon after noon the weather changed. The dense fog rolled away like a heavy cloud and suddenly the sun shot his bright rays over the island.

column2: Very good! exclaimed King Kitticut. We shall have a pleasant afternoon, I am sure, and he blew out the candles.
column3: Very good! exclaimed King Kitticut. We shall have a pleasant afternoon, I am sure, and he blew out the candles.

column2: Then he stood a moment motionless, as if turned to stone, for a terrible cry from without the palace reached his ears a cry so full of fear and horror that the King's heart almost stopped beating.
column3: Then he stood a moment motionless, as if turned to stone, for a terrible cry from without the palace reached his ears a cry so full of fear and horror that the King's heart almost stopped beating.

column2: Immediately there was a scurrying of feet as every one in the palace, filled with dismay, rushed outside to see what had happened.
column3: Immediately there was a scurrying of feet as every one in the palace, filled with dismay, rushed outside to see what had happened.

column2: Even fat little Rinkitink sprang from his chair and followed his host and the others through the arched vestibule.
column3: Even fat little Rinkitink sprang from his chair and followed his host and the others through the arched vestibule.

column2: After many years the worst fears of King Kitticut were realized.
column3: After many years the worst fears of King Kitticut were realized.

column2: Landing upon the beach, which was but a few steps from the palace itself, were hundreds of boats, every one filled with a throng of fierce warriors.
column3: Landing upon the beach, which was but a few steps from the palace itself, were hundreds of boats, every one filled with a throng of fierce warriors.

column2: They sprang upon the land with wild shouts of defiance and rushed to the King's palace, waving aloft their swords and spears and battleaxes.
column3: They sprang upon the land with wild shouts of defiance and rushed to the King's palace, waving aloft their swords and spears and battleaxes.

column2: King Kitticut, so completely surprised that he was bewildered, gazed at the approaching host with terror and grief.
column3: King Kitticut, so completely surprised that he was bewildered, gazed at the approaching host with terror and grief.

column2: They are the men of Regos and Coregos! he groaned. We are, indeed, lost!
column3: They are the men of Regos and Coregos! he groaned. We are, indeed, lost!

column2: Then he bethought himself, for the first time, of his wonderful pearls.
column3: Then he bethought himself, for the first time, of his wonderful pearls.

column2: thinking he meant to escape.

column3: when the good King looked upon a sorry

column2: sight. The Queen and her maidens, the officers and servants of the royal household and all who had inhabited this end of the Island of Pingaree had been seized by the invaders and bound with ropes.
column3: sight. The Queen and her maidens, the officers and servants of the royal household and all who had inhabited this end of the Island of Pingaree had been seized by the invaders and bound with ropes.

column2: At once they began carrying their victims to the boats, tossing them in as unceremoniously as if they had been bales of merchandise.

column2: The King looked around for his son Inga, but failed to find the boy among the prisoners. Nor was the fat King, Rinkitink, to be seen anywhere about.
column3: The King looked around for his son Inga, but failed to find the boy among the prisoners. Nor was the fat King, Rinkitink, to be seen anywhere about.

column2: The warriors were swarming over the palace like bees in a hive, seeking anyone who might be in hiding, and after the search had been prolonged for some time the leader asked impatiently: Do you find anyone else?
column3: The warriors were swarming over the palace like bees in a hive, seeking anyone who might be in hiding, and after the search had been prolonged for some time the leader asked impatiently: Do you find anyone else?

column2: No, his men told him. We have captured them all.
column3: No, his men told him. We have captured them all.

column2: Then, commanded the leader, remove everything of value from the palace and tear down its walls and towers, so that not one stone remains upon another!
column3: Then, commanded the leader, remove everything of value from the palace and tear down its walls and towers, so that not one stone remains upon another!

column2: While the warriors were busy with this task we will return to the boy Prince, who, when the fog lifted and the sun came out, wakened from his sleep and began to climb down from his perch in the tree.
column3: While the warriors were busy with this task we will return to the boy Prince, who, when the fog lifted and the sun came out, wakened from his sleep and began to climb down from his perch in the tree.

column2: But the terrifying cries of the people, mingled with the shouts of the rude warriors, caused him to pause and listen eagerly.
column3: But the terrifying cries of the people, mingled with the shouts of the rude warriors, caused him to pause and listen eagerly.

column2: Then he climbed rapidly up the tree, far above his platform, to the topmost swaying branches. This tree, which Inga called his own, was somewhat taller than the other trees that surrounded it,
column3: Then he climbed rapidly up the tree, far above his platform, to the topmost swaying branches. This tree, which Inga called his own, was somewhat taller than the other trees that surrounded it,

column2: and when he had reached the top he pressed aside the leaves and saw a great fleet of boats upon the shore strange boats, with banners that he had never seen before.
column3: and when he had reached the top he pressed aside the leaves and saw a great fleet of boats upon the shore strange boats, with banners that he had never seen before.

column2: Turning to look upon his father's palace, he found it surrounded by a horde of enemies. Then Inga knew the truth: that the island had been invaded by the barbaric warriors from the north.
column3: Turning to look upon his father's palace, he found it surrounded by a horde of enemies. Then Inga knew the truth: that the island had been invaded by the barbaric warriors from the north.

column2: He grew so faint from the terror of it all that he might have fallen had he not wound his arms around a limb and clung fast until the dizzy feeling passed away.
column3: He grew so faint from the terror of it all that he might have fallen had he not wound his arms around a limb and clung fast until the dizzy feeling passed away.

column2: Then with his sash he bound himself to the limb and again ventured to look out through the leaves.
column3: Then with his sash he bound himself to the limb and again ventured to look out through the leaves.

column2: The warriors were now engaged in carrying King Kitticut and Queen Garee and all their other captives down to the boats, where they were thrown in and chained one to another.
column3: The warriors were now engaged in carrying King Kitticut and Queen Garee and all their other captives down to the boats, where they were thrown in and chained one to another.

column2: It was a dreadful sight for the Prince to witness, but he sat very still, concealed from the sight of anyone below by the bower of leafy branches around him.
column3: It was a dreadful sight for the Prince to witness, but he sat very still, concealed from the sight of anyone below by the bower of leafy branches around him.

column2: Inga knew very well that he could do nothing to help his beloved parents, and that if he came down he would only be forced to share their cruel fate.
column3: Inga knew very well that he could do nothing to help his beloved parents, and that if he came down he would only be forced to share their cruel fate.

column2: Now a procession of the Northmen passed between the boats and the palace, bearing the rich furniture, splendid draperies and rare ornaments of which the royal palace had been robbed,
column3: Now a procession of the Northmen passed between the boats and the palace, bearing the rich furniture, splendid draperies and rare ornaments of which the royal palace had been robbed,

column2: together with such food and other plunder as they could lay their hands upon.
column3: together with such food and other plunder as they could lay their hands upon.

column2: After this, the men of Regos and Coregos threw ropes around the marble domes and towers and hundreds of warriors tugged at these ropes until the domes and towers toppled and fell in ruins upon the ground.
column3: After this, the men of Regos and Coregos threw ropes around the marble domes and towers and hundreds of warriors tugged at these ropes until the domes and towers toppled and fell in ruins upon the ground.

column2: Then the walls themselves were torn down, till little remained of the beautiful palace but a vast heap of white marble blocks tumbled and scattered upon the ground.
column3: Then the walls themselves were torn down, till little remained of the beautiful palace but a vast heap of white marble blocks tumbled and scattered upon the ground.

column2: Prince Inga wept bitter tears of grief as he watched the ruin of his home; yet he was powerless to avert the destruction.
column3: Prince Inga wept bitter tears of grief as he watched the ruin of his home; yet he was powerless to avert the destruction.

column2: When the palace had been demolished, some of the warriors entered their boats and rowed along the coast of the island, while the others marched in a great body down the length of the island itself.
column3: When the palace had been demolished, some of the warriors entered their boats and rowed along the coast of the island, while the others marched in a great body down the length of the island itself.

column2: They were so numerous that they formed a line stretching from shore to shore and they destroyed every house they came to and took every inhabitant prisoner.
column3: They were so numerous that they formed a line stretching from shore to shore and they destroyed every house they came to and took every inhabitant prisoner.

column2: The pearl fishers who lived at the lower end of the island tried to escape in their boats, but they were soon overtaken and made prisoners, like the others.
column3: The pearl fishers who lived at the lower end of the island tried to escape in their boats, but they were soon overtaken and made prisoners, like the others.

column2: Nor was there any attempt to resist the foe, for the sharp spears and pikes and swords of the invaders terrified the hearts of the defenseless people of Pingaree,
column3: Nor was there any attempt to resist the foe, for the sharp spears and pikes and swords of the invaders terrified the hearts of the defenseless people of Pingaree,

column2: whose sole weapons were their oyster rakes.
column3: whose sole weapons were their oyster rakes.

column2: When night fell the whole of the Island of Pingaree had been conquered by the men of the North, and all its people were slaves of the conquerors.
column3: When night fell the whole of the Island of Pingaree had been conquered by the men of the North, and all its people were slaves of the conquerors.

column2: Next morning the men of Regos and Coregos, being capable of no further mischief, departed from the scene of their triumph, carrying their prisoners with them and taking also every boat to be found upon the island.
column3: Next morning the men of Regos and Coregos, being capable of no further mischief, departed from the scene of their triumph, carrying their prisoners with them and taking also every boat to be found upon the island.

column2: Many of the boats they had filled with rich plunder, with pearls and silks and velvets, with silver and gold ornaments and all the treasure that had made Pingaree famed as one of the richest kingdoms in the world.

column2: And the hundreds of slaves they had captured would be set to work in the mines of Regos and the grain fields of Coregos.
column3: And the hundreds of slaves they had captured would be set to work in the mines of Regos and the grain fields of Coregos.

column2: So complete was the victory of the Northmen that it is no wonder the warriors sang songs of triumph as they hastened back to their homes.
column3: So complete was the victory of the Northmen that it is no wonder the warriors sang songs of triumph as they hastened back to their homes.

column2: Great rewards were awaiting them when they showed the haughty King of Regos and the terrible Queen of Coregos the results of their ocean raid and conquest.

column2: All through that terrible night Prince Inga remained hidden in his tree. In the morning he watched the great fleet of boats depart for their own country,
column3: All through that terrible night Prince Inga remained hidden in his tree. In the morning he watched the great fleet of boats depart for their own country,

column2: carrying his parents and his countrymen with them, as well as everything of value the Island of Pingaree had contained.
column3: carrying his parents and his countrymen with them, as well as everything of value the Island of Pingaree had contained.

column3: Sad, indeed, were the boy's thoughts when the last of the boats had become a mere speck in the distance,

column3: but Inga did not dare leave his perch of safety until all of the craft of the invaders had disappeared beyond the horizon.

column2: Then he came down, very slowly and carefully, for he was weak from hunger and the long and weary watch, as he had been in the tree for twenty four hours without food.
column3: Then he came down, very slowly and carefully, for he was weak from hunger and the long and weary watch, as he had been in the tree for twenty four hours without food.

column2: The sun shone upon the beautiful green isle as brilliantly as if no ruthless invader had passed and laid it in ruins.
column3: The sun shone upon the beautiful green isle as brilliantly as if no ruthless invader had passed and laid it in ruins.

column2: The birds still chirped among the trees and the butterflies darted from flower to flower as happily as when the land was filled with a prosperous and contented people.
column3: The birds still chirped among the trees and the butterflies darted from flower to flower as happily as when the land was filled with a prosperous and contented people.

column2: Inga feared that only he was left of all his nation. Perhaps he might be obliged to pass his life there alone. He would not starve, for the sea would give him oysters and fish, and the trees fruit;
column3: Inga feared that only he was left of all his nation. Perhaps he might be obliged to pass his life there alone. He would not starve, for the sea would give him oysters and fish, and the trees fruit;

column2: yet the life that confronted him was far from enticing.
column3: yet the life that confronted him was far from enticing.

column2: The boy's first act was to walk over to where the palace had stood and search the ruins until he found some scraps of food that had been overlooked by the enemy.
column3: The boy's first act was to walk over to where the palace had stood and search the ruins until he found some scraps of food that had been overlooked by the enemy.

column2: He sat upon a block of marble and ate of this, and tears filled his eyes as he gazed upon the desolation around him.
column3: He sat upon a block of marble and ate of this, and tears filled his eyes as he gazed upon the desolation around him.

column2: But Inga tried to bear up bravely, and having satisfied his hunger he walked over to the well, intending to draw a bucket of drinking water.
column3: But Inga tried to bear up bravely, and having satisfied his hunger he walked over to the well, intending to draw a bucket of drinking water.

column2: Fortunately, this well had been overlooked by the invaders and the bucket was still fastened to the chain that wound around a stout wooden windlass.
column3: Fortunately, this well had been overlooked by the invaders and the bucket was still fastened to the chain that wound around a stout wooden windlass.

column2: Inga took hold of the crank and began letting the bucket down into the well, when suddenly he was startled by a muffled voice crying out: Be careful, up there!
column3: Inga took hold of the crank and began letting the bucket down into the well, when suddenly he was startled by a muffled voice crying out: Be careful, up there!

column2: The sound and the words seemed to indicate that the voice came from the bottom of the well, so Inga looked down. Nothing could be seen, on account of the darkness.
column3: The sound and the words seemed to indicate that the voice came from the bottom of the well, so Inga looked down. Nothing could be seen, on account of the darkness.

column2: Who are you? he shouted.
column3: Who are you? he shouted.

column2: It's I Rinkitink, came the answer, and the depths of the well echoed: Tink i tink i tink! in a ghostly manner.
column3: It's I Rinkitink, came the answer, and the depths of the well echoed: Tink i tink i tink! in a ghostly manner.

column2: Are you in the well? asked the boy, greatly surprised.
column3: Are you in the well? asked the boy, greatly surprised.

column2: Yes, and nearly drowned. I fell in while running from those terrible warriors, and I've been standing in this damp hole ever since, with my head just above the water.
column3: Yes, and nearly drowned. I fell in while running from those terrible warriors, and I've been standing in this damp hole ever since, with my head just above the water.

column2: It's lucky the well was no deeper, for had my head been under water, instead of above it hoo, hoo, hoo, keek, eek! under instead of over, you know why,
column3: It's lucky the well was no deeper, for had my head been under water, instead of above it hoo, hoo, hoo, keek, eek! under instead of over, you know why,

column2: then I wouldn't be talking to you now!
column3: then I wouldn't be talking to you now!

column2: Ha, hoo, hee! And the well dismally echoed: Ha, hoo, hee! which you must imagine was a laugh half merry and half sad.
column3: Ha, hoo, hee! And the well dismally echoed: Ha, hoo, hee! which you must imagine was a laugh half merry and half sad.

column2: I'm awfully sorry, cried the boy, in answer. I wonder you have the heart to laugh at all. But how am I to get you out?
column3: I'm awfully sorry, cried the boy, in answer. I wonder you have the heart to laugh at all. But how am I to get you out?

column2: I've been considering that all night, said Rinkitink, and I believe the best plan will be for you to let down the bucket to me, and I'll hold fast to it while you wind up the chain and so draw me to the top.
column3: I've been considering that all night, said Rinkitink, and I believe the best plan will be for you to let down the bucket to me, and I'll hold fast to it while you wind up the chain and so draw me to the top.

column2: I will try to do that, replied Inga, and he let the bucket down very carefully until he heard the King call out: I've got it! Now pull me up slowly,
column3: I will try to do that, replied Inga, and he let the bucket down very carefully until he heard the King call out: I've got it! Now pull me up slowly,

column2: my boy, slowly so I won't rub against the rough sides.
column3: my boy, slowly so I won't rub against the rough sides.

column2: Inga began winding up the chain, but King Rinkitink was so fat that he was very heavy and by the time the boy had managed to pull him halfway up the well his strength was gone.
column3: Inga began winding up the chain, but King Rinkitink was so fat that he was very heavy and by the time the boy had managed to pull him halfway up the well his strength was gone.

column2: He clung to the crank as long as possible, but suddenly it slipped from his grasp and the next minute he heard Rinkitink fall plump! into the water again.
column3: He clung to the crank as long as possible, but suddenly it slipped from his grasp and the next minute he heard Rinkitink fall plump! into the water again.

column2: That's too bad! called Inga, in real distress; but you were so heavy I couldn't help it.
column3: That's too bad! called Inga, in real distress; but you were so heavy I couldn't help it.

column2: Dear me! gasped the King, from the darkness below, as he spluttered and coughed to get the water out of his mouth. Why didn't you tell me you were going to let go?
column3: Dear me! gasped the King, from the darkness below, as he spluttered and coughed to get the water out of his mouth. Why didn't you tell me you were going to let go?

column2: I hadn't time, said Inga, sorrowfully.
column3: I hadn't time, said Inga, sorrowfully.

column2: Well, I'm not suffering from thirst, declared the King, for there's enough water inside me to float all the boats of Regos and Coregos or at least it feels that way.
column3: Well, I'm not suffering from thirst, declared the King, for there's enough water inside me to float all the boats of Regos and Coregos or at least it feels that way.

column2: But never mind! So long as I'm not actually drowned, what does it matter?
column3: But never mind! So long as I'm not actually drowned, what does it matter?

column2: What shall we do next? asked the boy anxiously.
column3: What shall we do next? asked the boy anxiously.

column2: Call someone to help you, was the reply.
column3: Call someone to help you, was the reply.

column2: There is no one on the island but myself, said the boy; excepting you, he added, as an afterthought.
column3: There is no one on the island but myself, said the boy; excepting you, he added, as an afterthought.

column2: I'm not on it more's the pity! but in it, responded Rinkitink. Are the warriors all gone?
column3: I'm not on it more's the pity! but in it, responded Rinkitink. Are the warriors all gone?

column2: Yes, said Inga, and they have taken my father and mother, and all our people, to be their slaves, he added, trying in vain to repress a sob.
column3: Yes, said Inga, and they have taken my father and mother, and all our people, to be their slaves, he added, trying in vain to repress a sob.

column2: So so! said Rinkitink softly; and then he paused a moment, as if in thought. Finally he said: There are worse things than slavery, but I never imagined a well could be one of them.
column3: So so! said Rinkitink softly; and then he paused a moment, as if in thought. Finally he said: There are worse things than slavery, but I never imagined a well could be one of them.

column2: Tell me, Inga, could you let down some food to me? I'm nearly starved, and if you could manage to send me down some food I'd be well fed hoo, hoo, heek, keek, eek!
column3: Tell me, Inga, could you let down some food to me? I'm nearly starved, and if you could manage to send me down some food I'd be well fed hoo, hoo, heek, keek, eek!

column2: well fed. Do you see the joke, Inga?
column3: well fed. Do you see the joke, Inga?

column2: Do not ask me to enjoy a joke just now, Your Majesty, begged Inga in a sad voice; but if you will be patient I will try to find something for you to eat.
column3: Do not ask me to enjoy a joke just now, Your Majesty, begged Inga in a sad voice; but if you will be patient I will try to find something for you to eat.

column2: He ran back to the ruins of the palace and began searching for bits of food with which to satisfy the hunger of the King, when to his surprise he observed the goat,
column3: He ran back to the ruins of the palace and began searching for bits of food with which to satisfy the hunger of the King, when to his surprise he observed the goat,

column2: Bilbil, wandering among the marble blocks.

column2: What! cried Inga. Didn't the warriors get you, either?
column3: What! cried Inga. Didn't the warriors get you, either?

column2: If they had, calmly replied Bilbil, I shouldn't be here.
column3: If they had, calmly replied Bilbil, I shouldn't be here.

column2: But how did you escape? asked the boy.
column3: But how did you escape? asked the boy.

column2: Easily enough. I kept my mouth shut and stayed away from the rascals, said the goat. I knew that the soldiers would not care for a skinny old beast like me,
column3: Easily enough. I kept my mouth shut and stayed away from the rascals, said the goat. I knew that the soldiers would not care for a skinny old beast like me,

column2: for to the eye of a stranger I seem good for nothing.
column3: for to the eye of a stranger I seem good for nothing.

column3: Had they known I could talk, and that my head contained more wisdom than a hundred of their own noddles, I might not have escaped so easily.

column2: Perhaps you are right, said the boy.
column3: Perhaps you are right, said the boy.

column2: I suppose they got the old man? carelessly remarked Bilbil.
column3: I suppose they got the old man? carelessly remarked Bilbil.

column2: What old man?
column3: What old man?

column2: Rinkitink.
column3: Rinkitink.

column2: Oh, no! His Majesty is at the bottom of the well, said Inga, and I don't know how to get him out again.
column3: Oh, no! His Majesty is at the bottom of the well, said Inga, and I don't know how to get him out again.

column2: Then let him stay there, suggested the goat.
column3: Then let him stay there, suggested the goat.

column2: That would be cruel. I am sure, Bilbil, that you are fond of the good King, your master, and do not mean what you say. Together, let us find some way to save poor King Rinkitink.

column2: He is a very jolly companion, and has a heart exceedingly kind and gentle.

column2: You might have broken your neck in the fall, or been drowned in the water.

column3: Bilbil, replied the King solemnly, you're a goat. Do you imagine I fell down the well on purpose?

column3: I imagine nothing, retorted Bilbil. I only know you were there.

column2: How did it happen? inquired Inga.

column2: So I'm glad the enemy did not find me, Bilbil. How many others escaped?
column3: So I'm glad the enemy did not find me, Bilbil. How many others escaped?

column2: That I do not know, replied the boy, for I have not yet had time to visit the other parts of the island. When you have rested and satisfied your royal hunger,

column3: Hearing this, Bilbil cast a surly glance at his master but said nothing, since it was really the goat's business to carry King Rinkitink wherever he desired to go.

column2: They first searched the ruins of the palace, and where the kitchen had once been they found a small quantity of food that had been half hidden by a block of marble.
column3: They first searched the ruins of the palace, and where the kitchen had once been they found a small quantity of food that had been half hidden by a block of marble.

column2: This they carefully placed in a sack to preserve it for future use, the little fat King having first eaten as much as he cared for.

column2: Prince Inga walking by his side.

column2: They found on every hand ruin and desolation. The houses of the people had been pilfered of all valuables and then torn down or burned.
column3: They found on every hand ruin and desolation. The houses of the people had been pilfered of all valuables and then torn down or burned.

column2: Not a boat had been left upon the shore, nor was there a single person, man or woman or child, remaining upon the island, save themselves.
column3: Not a boat had been left upon the shore, nor was there a single person, man or woman or child, remaining upon the island, save themselves.

column2: The only inhabitants of Pingaree now consisted of a fat little King, a boy and a goat.
column3: The only inhabitants of Pingaree now consisted of a fat little King, a boy and a goat.

column2: Even Rinkitink, merry hearted as he was, found it hard to laugh in the face of this mighty disaster. Even the goat, contrary to its usual habit,

column2: refrained from saying anything disagreeable.

column3: As for the poor boy whose home was now a wilderness, the tears came often to his eyes as he marked the ruin of his dearly loved island.

column2: When, at nightfall, they reached the lower end of Pingaree and found it swept as bare as the rest, Inga's grief was almost more than he could bear.
column3: When, at nightfall, they reached the lower end of Pingaree and found it swept as bare as the rest, Inga's grief was almost more than he could bear.

column2: Everything had been swept from him parents, home and country in so brief a time that his bewilderment was equal to his sorrow.
column3: Everything had been swept from him parents, home and country in so brief a time that his bewilderment was equal to his sorrow.

column2: Since no house remained standing, in which they might sleep, the three wanderers crept beneath the overhanging branches of a cassa tree and curled themselves up as comfortably as possible.
column3: Since no house remained standing, in which they might sleep, the three wanderers crept beneath the overhanging branches of a cassa tree and curled themselves up as comfortably as possible.

column2: So tired and exhausted were they by the day's anxieties and griefs that their troubles soon faded into the mists of dreamland.
column3: So tired and exhausted were they by the day's anxieties and griefs that their troubles soon faded into the mists of dreamland.

column3: Bilbil, said the King, squatting down beside the goat and resting his fat chin upon his hands and his elbows on his knees, allow me to confide to you the fact that I am bored, and need amusement.

column2: I am the King and you are the goat. Suppose you tell me a story.

column3: Suppose I don't, said Bilbil, with a scowl, for a goat's face is very expressive.

column3: The goat looked at him with an expression of scorn. Said he: One would think you are but four years old, Rinkitink! But there I will do as you command.

column2: Listen carefully, and the story may do you some good although I doubt if you understand the moral.
column3: Listen carefully, and the story may do you some good although I doubt if you understand the moral.

column3: I am sure the story will do me good, declared the King, whose eyes were twinkling.

column2: Once on a time, began the goat.
column3: Once on a time, began the goat.

column2: When was that, Bilbil? asked the King gently.
column3: When was that, Bilbil? asked the King gently.

column2: Don't interrupt; it is impolite. Once on a time there was a King with a hollow inside his head, where most people have their brains, and Is this a true story, Bilbil?
column3: Don't interrupt; it is impolite. Once on a time there was a King with a hollow inside his head, where most people have their brains, and Is this a true story, Bilbil?

column3: And the King with a hollow head could chatter words, which had no sense, and laugh in a brainless manner at senseless things. That part of the story is true enough, Rinkitink.

column3: Then proceed with the tale, sweet Bilbil. Yet it is hard to believe that any King could be brainless unless, indeed, he proved it by owning a talking goat.

column3: Bilbil glared at him a full minute in silence. Then he resumed his story: This empty headed man was a King by accident, having been born to that high station.
