column2: While he was considering this matter, King Rinkitink came waddling up to him and said: Well, well, well, my Prince, your words have come true!
column3: While he was considering this matter, King Rinkitink came waddling up to him and said: Well, well, well, my Prince, your words have come true!

column2: Here is the boat, for a certainty, yet how it came here and how you knew it would come to us are puzzles that mystify me.
column3: Here is the boat, for a certainty, yet how it came here and how you knew it would come to us are puzzles that mystify me.

column2: I do not question our good fortune, however, and my heart is bubbling with joy, for in this boat I will return at once to my City of Gilgad, from which I have remained absent altogether too long a time.
column3: I do not question our good fortune, however, and my heart is bubbling with joy, for in this boat I will return at once to my City of Gilgad, from which I have remained absent altogether too long a time.

column2: I do not wish to go to Gilgad, said Inga.
column3: I do not wish to go to Gilgad, said Inga.

column2: That is too bad, my friend, for you would be very welcome. But you may remain upon this island, if you wish, continued Rinkitink, and when I get home I will send some of my people to rescue you.
column3: That is too bad, my friend, for you would be very welcome. But you may remain upon this island, if you wish, continued Rinkitink, and when I get home I will send some of my people to rescue you.

column2: It is my boat, Your Majesty, said Inga quietly.
column3: It is my boat, Your Majesty, said Inga quietly.

column2: May be, may be, was the careless answer, but I am King of a great country, while you are a boy Prince without any kingdom to speak of.
column3: May be, may be, was the careless answer, but I am King of a great country, while you are a boy Prince without any kingdom to speak of.

column2: Therefore, being of greater importance than you, it is just and right that I take, your boat and return to my own country in it.
column3: Therefore, being of greater importance than you, it is just and right that I take, your boat and return to my own country in it.

column2: I am sorry to differ from Your Majesty's views, said Inga, but instead of going to Gilgad I consider it of greater importance that we go to the islands of Regos and Coregos.
column3: I am sorry to differ from Your Majesty's views, said Inga, but instead of going to Gilgad I consider it of greater importance that we go to the islands of Regos and Coregos.

column2: Hey? What! cried the astounded King. To Regos and Coregos! To become slaves of the barbarians, like the King, your father? No, no, my boy!
column3: Hey? What! cried the astounded King. To Regos and Coregos! To become slaves of the barbarians, like the King, your father? No, no, my boy!

column2: Your Uncle Rinki may have an empty noddle, as Bilbil claims, but he is far too wise to put his head in the lion's mouth. It's no fun to be a slave.
column3: Your Uncle Rinki may have an empty noddle, as Bilbil claims, but he is far too wise to put his head in the lion's mouth. It's no fun to be a slave.

column2: The people of Regos and Coregos will not enslave us, declared Inga.
column3: The people of Regos and Coregos will not enslave us, declared Inga.

column2: On the contrary, it is my intention to set free my dear parents, as well as all my people, and to bring them back again to Pingaree.
column3: On the contrary, it is my intention to set free my dear parents, as well as all my people, and to bring them back again to Pingaree.

column2: Cheek eek eek eek eek! How funny! chuckled Rinkitink, winking at the goat, which scowled in return. Your audacity takes my breath away, Inga,
column3: Cheek eek eek eek eek! How funny! chuckled Rinkitink, winking at the goat, which scowled in return. Your audacity takes my breath away, Inga,

column2: but the adventure has its charm, I must, confess.
column3: but the adventure has its charm, I must, confess.

column2: Were I not so fat, I'd agree to your plan at once, and could probably conquer that horde of fierce warriors without any assistance at all any at all eh, Bilbil?
column3: Were I not so fat, I'd agree to your plan at once, and could probably conquer that horde of fierce warriors without any assistance at all any at all eh, Bilbil?

column2: But I grieve to say that I am fat, and not in good fighting trim.
column3: But I grieve to say that I am fat, and not in good fighting trim.

column2: As for your determination to do what I admit I can't do, Inga, I fear you forget that you are only a boy, and rather small at that.
column3: As for your determination to do what I admit I can't do, Inga, I fear you forget that you are only a boy, and rather small at that.

column2: No, I do not forget that, was Inga's reply.
column3: No, I do not forget that, was Inga's reply.

column2: Then please consider that you and I and Bilbil are not strong enough, as an army, to conquer a powerful nation of skilled warriors.
column3: Then please consider that you and I and Bilbil are not strong enough, as an army, to conquer a powerful nation of skilled warriors.

column2: We could attempt it, of course, but you are too young to die, while I am too old. Come with me to my City of Gilgad, where you will be greatly honored.
column3: We could attempt it, of course, but you are too young to die, while I am too old. Come with me to my City of Gilgad, where you will be greatly honored.

column2: I'll have my professors teach you how to be good. Eh? What do you say?
column3: I'll have my professors teach you how to be good. Eh? What do you say?

column2: Inga was a little embarrassed how to reply to these arguments, which he knew King Rinkitink considered were wise; so, after a period of thought, he said:
column3: Inga was a little embarrassed how to reply to these arguments, which he knew King Rinkitink considered were wise; so, after a period of thought, he said:

column2: I will make a bargain with Your Majesty, for I do not wish to fail in respect to so worthy a man and so great a King as yourself.
column3: I will make a bargain with Your Majesty, for I do not wish to fail in respect to so worthy a man and so great a King as yourself.

column2: This boat is mine, as I have said, and in my father's absence you have become my guest; therefore I claim that I am entitled to some consideration, as well as you.
column3: This boat is mine, as I have said, and in my father's absence you have become my guest; therefore I claim that I am entitled to some consideration, as well as you.

column2: No doubt of it, agreed Rinkitink. What is the bargain you propose, Inga?
column3: No doubt of it, agreed Rinkitink. What is the bargain you propose, Inga?

column2: Let us both get into the boat, and you shall first try to row us to Gilgad. If you succeed, I will accompany you right willingly; but should you fail,
column3: Let us both get into the boat, and you shall first try to row us to Gilgad. If you succeed, I will accompany you right willingly; but should you fail,

column2: I will then row the boat to Regos, and you must come with me without further protest.
column3: I will then row the boat to Regos, and you must come with me without further protest.

column2: A fair and just bargain! cried the King, highly pleased. Yet, although I am a man of mighty deeds, I do not relish the prospect of rowing so big a boat all the way to Gilgad.
column3: A fair and just bargain! cried the King, highly pleased. Yet, although I am a man of mighty deeds, I do not relish the prospect of rowing so big a boat all the way to Gilgad.

column2: But I will do my best and abide by the result.
column3: But I will do my best and abide by the result.

column2: The matter being thus peaceably settled, they prepared to embark.
column3: The matter being thus peaceably settled, they prepared to embark.

column2: A further supply of fruits was placed in the boat and Inga also raked up a quantity of the delicious oysters that abounded on the coast of Pingaree but which he had before been unable to reach for lack of a boat.
column3: A further supply of fruits was placed in the boat and Inga also raked up a quantity of the delicious oysters that abounded on the coast of Pingaree but which he had before been unable to reach for lack of a boat.

column2: This was done at the suggestion of the ever hungry Rinkitink, and when the oysters had been stowed in their shells behind the water barrel and a plentiful supply of grass brought aboard for Bilbil,
column3: This was done at the suggestion of the ever hungry Rinkitink, and when the oysters had been stowed in their shells behind the water barrel and a plentiful supply of grass brought aboard for Bilbil,

column2: they decided they were ready to start on their voyage.
column3: they decided they were ready to start on their voyage.

column2: It proved no easy task to get Bilbil into the boat, for he was a remarkably clumsy goat and once, when Rinkitink gave him a push, he tumbled into the water and nearly drowned before they could get him out again.
column3: It proved no easy task to get Bilbil into the boat, for he was a remarkably clumsy goat and once, when Rinkitink gave him a push, he tumbled into the water and nearly drowned before they could get him out again.

column2: But there was no thought of leaving the quaint animal behind.
column3: But there was no thought of leaving the quaint animal behind.

column2: His power of speech made him seem almost human in the eyes of the boy, and the fat King was so accustomed to his surly companion that nothing could have induced him to part with him.
column3: His power of speech made him seem almost human in the eyes of the boy, and the fat King was so accustomed to his surly companion that nothing could have induced him to part with him.

column2: Finally Bilbil fell sprawling into the bottom of the boat, and Inga helped him to get to the front end, where there was enough space for him to lie down.
column3: Finally Bilbil fell sprawling into the bottom of the boat, and Inga helped him to get to the front end, where there was enough space for him to lie down.

column2: Rinkitink now took his seat in the silver lined craft and the boy came last, pushing off the boat as he sprang aboard, so that it floated freely upon the water.
column3: Rinkitink now took his seat in the silver lined craft and the boy came last, pushing off the boat as he sprang aboard, so that it floated freely upon the water.

column2: Well, here we go for Gilgad! exclaimed the King, picking up the oars and placing them in the row locks. Then he began to row as hard as he could,
column3: Well, here we go for Gilgad! exclaimed the King, picking up the oars and placing them in the row locks. Then he began to row as hard as he could,

column2: singing at the same time an odd sort of a song that ran like this:
column3: singing at the same time an odd sort of a song that ran like this:

column2: The way to Gilgad isn't bad For a stout old King and a brave young lad, For a cross old goat with a dripping coat, And a silver boat in which to float.
column3: The way to Gilgad isn't bad For a stout old King and a brave young lad, For a cross old goat with a dripping coat, And a silver boat in which to float.

column2: So our hearts are merry, light and glad As we speed away to fair Gilgad!
column3: So our hearts are merry, light and glad As we speed away to fair Gilgad!

column2: Don't, Rinkitink; please don't! It makes me seasick, growled Bilbil.
column3: Don't, Rinkitink; please don't! It makes me seasick, growled Bilbil.

column2: Rinkitink stopped rowing, for by this time he was all out of breath and his round face was covered with big drops of perspiration.
column3: Rinkitink stopped rowing, for by this time he was all out of breath and his round face was covered with big drops of perspiration.

column2: And when he looked over his shoulder he found to his dismay that the boat had scarcely moved a foot from its former position.
column3: And when he looked over his shoulder he found to his dismay that the boat had scarcely moved a foot from its former position.

column2: Inga said nothing and appeared not to notice the King's failure. So now Rinkitink, with a serious look on his fat, red face, took off his purple robe and rolled up the sleeves of his tunic and tried again.
column3: Inga said nothing and appeared not to notice the King's failure. So now Rinkitink, with a serious look on his fat, red face, took off his purple robe and rolled up the sleeves of his tunic and tried again.

column2: However, he succeeded no better than before and when he heard Bilbil give a gruff laugh and saw a smile upon the boy Prince's face, Rinkitink suddenly dropped the oars and began shouting with laughter at his own defeat.
column3: However, he succeeded no better than before and when he heard Bilbil give a gruff laugh and saw a smile upon the boy Prince's face, Rinkitink suddenly dropped the oars and began shouting with laughter at his own defeat.

column2: As he wiped his brow with a yellow silk handkerchief he sang in a merry voice: A sailor bold am I, I hold, But boldness will not row a boat.
column3: As he wiped his brow with a yellow silk handkerchief he sang in a merry voice: A sailor bold am I, I hold, But boldness will not row a boat.

column2: So I confess I'm in distress And just as useless as the goat.
column3: So I confess I'm in distress And just as useless as the goat.

column2: Please leave me out of your verses, said Bilbil with a snort of anger.
column3: Please leave me out of your verses, said Bilbil with a snort of anger.

column2: When I make a fool of myself, Bilbil, I'm a goat, replied Rinkitink.
column3: When I make a fool of myself, Bilbil, I'm a goat, replied Rinkitink.

column2: Not so, insisted Bilbil. Nothing could make you a member of my superior race.
column3: Not so, insisted Bilbil. Nothing could make you a member of my superior race.

column2: Superior? Why, Bilbil, a goat is but a beast, while I am a King!
column3: Superior? Why, Bilbil, a goat is but a beast, while I am a King!

column2: I claim that superiority lies in intelligence, said the goat.
column3: I claim that superiority lies in intelligence, said the goat.

column2: Rinkitink paid no attention to this remark, but turning to Inga he said: We may as well get back to the shore, for the boat is too heavy to row to Gilgad or anywhere else.
column3: Rinkitink paid no attention to this remark, but turning to Inga he said: We may as well get back to the shore, for the boat is too heavy to row to Gilgad or anywhere else.

column2: Indeed, it will be hard for us to reach land again.
column3: Indeed, it will be hard for us to reach land again.

column2: Let me take the oars, suggested Inga. You must not forget our bargain.
column3: Let me take the oars, suggested Inga. You must not forget our bargain.

column2: No, indeed, answered Rinkitink. If you can row us to Regos, or to any other place, I will go with you without protest.
column3: No, indeed, answered Rinkitink. If you can row us to Regos, or to any other place, I will go with you without protest.

column2: So the King took Inga's place at the stern of the boat and the boy grasped the oars and commenced to row.
column3: So the King took Inga's place at the stern of the boat and the boy grasped the oars and commenced to row.

column2: And now, to the great wonder of Rinkitink and even to Inga's surprise the oars became light as feathers as soon as the Prince took hold of them.
column3: And now, to the great wonder of Rinkitink and even to Inga's surprise the oars became light as feathers as soon as the Prince took hold of them.

column2: In an instant the boat began to glide rapidly through the water and, seeing this, the boy turned its prow toward the north.
column3: In an instant the boat began to glide rapidly through the water and, seeing this, the boy turned its prow toward the north.

column2: He did not know exactly where Regos and Coregos were located, but he did know that the islands lay to the north of Pingaree, so he decided to trust to luck and the guidance of the pearls to carry him to them.
column3: He did not know exactly where Regos and Coregos were located, but he did know that the islands lay to the north of Pingaree, so he decided to trust to luck and the guidance of the pearls to carry him to them.

column2: Gradually the Island of Pingaree became smaller to their view as the boat sped onward,
column3: Gradually the Island of Pingaree became smaller to their view as the boat sped onward,

column2: until at the end of an hour they had lost sight of it altogether and were wholly surrounded by the purple waters of the Nonestic Ocean.
column3: until at the end of an hour they had lost sight of it altogether and were wholly surrounded by the purple waters of the Nonestic Ocean.

column2: Prince Inga did not tire from the labor of rowing; indeed, it seemed to him no labor at all.
column3: Prince Inga did not tire from the labor of rowing; indeed, it seemed to him no labor at all.

column2: Once he stopped long enough to place the poles of the canopy in the holes that had been made for them,
column3: Once he stopped long enough to place the poles of the canopy in the holes that had been made for them,

column2: in the edges of the boat, and to spread the canopy of silver over the poles, for Rinkitink had complained of the sun's heat.
column3: in the edges of the boat, and to spread the canopy of silver over the poles, for Rinkitink had complained of the sun's heat.

column2: But the canopy shut out the hot rays and rendered the interior of the boat cool and pleasant.
column3: But the canopy shut out the hot rays and rendered the interior of the boat cool and pleasant.

column2: This is a glorious ride! cried Rinkitink, as he lay back in the shade. I find it a decided relief to be away from that dismal island of Pingaree.
column3: This is a glorious ride! cried Rinkitink, as he lay back in the shade. I find it a decided relief to be away from that dismal island of Pingaree.

column2: It may be a relief for a short time, said Bilbil, but you are going to the land of your enemies, who will probably stick your fat body full of spears and arrows.
column3: It may be a relief for a short time, said Bilbil, but you are going to the land of your enemies, who will probably stick your fat body full of spears and arrows.

column2: Oh, I hope not! exclaimed Inga, distressed at the thought.
column3: Oh, I hope not! exclaimed Inga, distressed at the thought.

column2: Never mind, said the King calmly, a man can die but once, you know, and when the enemy kills me I shall beg him to kill Bilbil, also, that we may remain together in death as in life.
column3: Never mind, said the King calmly, a man can die but once, you know, and when the enemy kills me I shall beg him to kill Bilbil, also, that we may remain together in death as in life.

column2: They may be cannibals, in which case they will roast and eat us, suggested Bilbil, who wished to terrify his master.
column3: They may be cannibals, in which case they will roast and eat us, suggested Bilbil, who wished to terrify his master.

column2: Who knows? answered Rinkitink, with a shudder. But cheer up, Bilbil; they may not kill us after all, or even capture us; so let us not borrow trouble.
column3: Who knows? answered Rinkitink, with a shudder. But cheer up, Bilbil; they may not kill us after all, or even capture us; so let us not borrow trouble.

column2: Do not look so cross, my sprightly quadruped, and I will sing to amuse you.
column3: Do not look so cross, my sprightly quadruped, and I will sing to amuse you.

column2: Your song would make me more cross than ever, grumbled the goat.
column3: Your song would make me more cross than ever, grumbled the goat.

column2: Quite impossible, dear Bilbil. You couldn't be more surly if you tried. So here is a famous song for you.
column3: Quite impossible, dear Bilbil. You couldn't be more surly if you tried. So here is a famous song for you.

column2: While the boy rowed steadily on and the boat rushed fast over the water, the jolly King, who never could be sad or serious for many minutes at a time,
column3: While the boy rowed steadily on and the boat rushed fast over the water, the jolly King, who never could be sad or serious for many minutes at a time,

column2: lay back on his embroidered cushions and sang as follows:
column3: lay back on his embroidered cushions and sang as follows:

column2: A merry maiden went to sea Sing too ral oo ral i do!
column3: A merry maiden went to sea Sing too ral oo ral i do!

column2: She sat upon the Captain's knee And looked around the sea to see What she could see, but she couldn't see me Sing too ral oo ral i do!
column3: She sat upon the Captain's knee And looked around the sea to see What she could see, but she couldn't see me Sing too ral oo ral i do!

column2: How do you like that, Bilbil?
column3: How do you like that, Bilbil?

column2: I don't like it, complained the goat. It reminds me of the alligator that tried to whistle.
column3: I don't like it, complained the goat. It reminds me of the alligator that tried to whistle.

column2: Did he succeed, Bilbil? asked the King.
column3: Did he succeed, Bilbil? asked the King.

column2: He whistled as well as you sing.
column3: He whistled as well as you sing.

column2: Ha, ha, ha, ha, heek, keek, eek! chuckled the King. He must have whistled most exquisitely, eh, my friend?
column3: Ha, ha, ha, ha, heek, keek, eek! chuckled the King. He must have whistled most exquisitely, eh, my friend?

column2: I am not your friend, returned the goat, wagging his ears in a surly manner.
column3: I am not your friend, returned the goat, wagging his ears in a surly manner.

column2: I am yours, however, was the King's cheery reply; and to prove it I'll sing you another verse.
column3: I am yours, however, was the King's cheery reply; and to prove it I'll sing you another verse.

column2: Don't, I beg of you!
column3: Don't, I beg of you!

column2: But the King sang as follows: The wind blew off the maiden's shoe Sing too ral oo ral i do!
column3: But the King sang as follows: The wind blew off the maiden's shoe Sing too ral oo ral i do!

column2: And the shoe flew high to the sky so blue And the maiden knew 'twas a new shoe, too; But she couldn't pursue the shoe, 'tis true Sing too ral oo ral i do!
column3: And the shoe flew high to the sky so blue And the maiden knew 'twas a new shoe, too; But she couldn't pursue the shoe, 'tis true Sing too ral oo ral i do!

column2: Isn't that sweet, my pretty goat?
column3: Isn't that sweet, my pretty goat?

column2: Sweet, do you ask? retorted Bilbil. I consider it as sweet as candy made from mustard and vinegar.
column3: Sweet, do you ask? retorted Bilbil. I consider it as sweet as candy made from mustard and vinegar.

column2: But not as sweet as your disposition, I admit. Ah, Bilbil, your temper would put honey itself to shame.
column3: But not as sweet as your disposition, I admit. Ah, Bilbil, your temper would put honey itself to shame.

column2: Do not quarrel, I beg of you, pleaded Inga. Are we not sad enough already?
column3: Do not quarrel, I beg of you, pleaded Inga. Are we not sad enough already?

column2: But this is a jolly quarrel, said the King, and it is the way Bilbil and I often amuse ourselves. Listen, now, to the last verse of all: The maid who shied her shoe now cried Sing too ral oo ral i do!
column3: But this is a jolly quarrel, said the King, and it is the way Bilbil and I often amuse ourselves. Listen, now, to the last verse of all: The maid who shied her shoe now cried Sing too ral oo ral i do!

column2: Her tears were fried for the Captain's bride Who ate with pride her sobs, beside, And gently sighed 'I'm satisfied' Sing to ral oo ral i do!
column3: Her tears were fried for the Captain's bride Who ate with pride her sobs, beside, And gently sighed 'I'm satisfied' Sing to ral oo ral i do!

column2: Worse and worse! grumbled Bilbil, with much scorn. I am glad that is the last verse, for another of the same kind might cause me to faint.
column3: Worse and worse! grumbled Bilbil, with much scorn. I am glad that is the last verse, for another of the same kind might cause me to faint.

column2: I fear you have no ear for music, said the King.
column3: I fear you have no ear for music, said the King.

column2: I have heard no music, as yet, declared the goat. You must have a strong imagination, King Rinkitink, if you consider your songs music.
column3: I have heard no music, as yet, declared the goat. You must have a strong imagination, King Rinkitink, if you consider your songs music.

column2: Do you remember the story of the bear that hired out for a nursemaid?
column3: Do you remember the story of the bear that hired out for a nursemaid?

column2: I do not recall it just now, said Rinkitink, with a wink at Inga.
column3: I do not recall it just now, said Rinkitink, with a wink at Inga.

column2: Well, the bear tried to sing a lullaby to put the baby to sleep.
column3: Well, the bear tried to sing a lullaby to put the baby to sleep.

column2: And then? said the King.
column3: And then? said the King.

column2: The bear was highly pleased with its own voice, but the baby was nearly frightened to death.
column3: The bear was highly pleased with its own voice, but the baby was nearly frightened to death.

column2: Heh, heb, heh, heh, whoo, hoo, hoo! You are a merry rogue, Bilbil, laughed the King; a merry rogue in spite of your gloomy features.
column3: Heh, heb, heh, heh, whoo, hoo, hoo! You are a merry rogue, Bilbil, laughed the King; a merry rogue in spite of your gloomy features.

column2: However, if I have not amused you, I have at least pleased myself, for I am exceedingly fond of a good song. So let us say no more about it.
column3: However, if I have not amused you, I have at least pleased myself, for I am exceedingly fond of a good song. So let us say no more about it.

column2: All this time the boy Prince was rowing the boat. He was not in the least tired, for the oars he held seemed to move of their own accord.
column3: All this time the boy Prince was rowing the boat. He was not in the least tired, for the oars he held seemed to move of their own accord.

column2: He paid little heed to the conversation of Rinkitink and the goat, but busied his thoughts with plans of what he should do when he reached the islands of Regos and Coregos and confronted his enemies.
column3: He paid little heed to the conversation of Rinkitink and the goat, but busied his thoughts with plans of what he should do when he reached the islands of Regos and Coregos and confronted his enemies.

column2: When the others finally became silent, Inga inquired.
column3: When the others finally became silent, Inga inquired.

column2: Can you fight, King Rinkitink?
column3: Can you fight, King Rinkitink?

column2: I have never tried, was the answer. In time of danger I have found it much easier to run away than to face the foe.
column3: I have never tried, was the answer. In time of danger I have found it much easier to run away than to face the foe.

column2: But could you fight? asked the boy.
column3: But could you fight? asked the boy.

column2: I might try, if there was no chance to escape by running. Have you a proper weapon for me to fight with?
column3: I might try, if there was no chance to escape by running. Have you a proper weapon for me to fight with?

column2: I have no weapon at all, confessed Inga.
column3: I have no weapon at all, confessed Inga.

column2: Then let us use argument and persuasion instead of fighting. For instance, if we could persuade the warriors of Regos to lie down, and let me step on them,
column3: Then let us use argument and persuasion instead of fighting. For instance, if we could persuade the warriors of Regos to lie down, and let me step on them,

column2: they would be crushed with ease.
column3: they would be crushed with ease.

column2: Prince Inga had expected little support from the King, so he was not discouraged by this answer. After all, he reflected, a conquest by battle would be out of the question,
column3: Prince Inga had expected little support from the King, so he was not discouraged by this answer. After all, he reflected, a conquest by battle would be out of the question,

column2: yet the White Pearl would not have advised him to go to Regos and Coregos had the mission been a hopeless one. It seemed to him, on further reflection,
column3: yet the White Pearl would not have advised him to go to Regos and Coregos had the mission been a hopeless one. It seemed to him, on further reflection,

column2: that he must rely upon circumstances to determine his actions when he reached the islands of the barbarians.
column3: that he must rely upon circumstances to determine his actions when he reached the islands of the barbarians.

column2: By this time Inga felt perfect confidence in the Magic Pearls. It was the White Pearl that had given him the boat, and the Blue Pearl that had given him strength to row it.
column3: By this time Inga felt perfect confidence in the Magic Pearls. It was the White Pearl that had given him the boat, and the Blue Pearl that had given him strength to row it.

column2: He believed that the Pink Pearl would protect him from any danger that might arise; so his anxiety was not for himself, but for his companions.
column3: He believed that the Pink Pearl would protect him from any danger that might arise; so his anxiety was not for himself, but for his companions.

column2: King Rinkitink and the goat had no magic to protect them, so Inga resolved to do all in his power to keep them from harm.
column3: King Rinkitink and the goat had no magic to protect them, so Inga resolved to do all in his power to keep them from harm.

column2: who abandoned his city and crossed the bridge of boats to the Island of Coregos.

column2: The humble citizens and serving people of Regos, who had been terrified and abused by the rough warriors all their lives, were not only greatly astonished by this sudden conquest of their masters but greatly delighted.
column3: The humble citizens and serving people of Regos, who had been terrified and abused by the rough warriors all their lives, were not only greatly astonished by this sudden conquest of their masters but greatly delighted.

column2: As the King and his army fled to Coregos, the people embraced one another and danced for very joy, and then they turned to see what the conquerors of Regos were like.

column2: Oh, here comes the army of King Rinkitink!
column3: Oh, here comes the army of King Rinkitink!

column2: It isn't a big one, perhaps you may think, But it scattered the warriors quicker than wink Rink i tink, tink i tink, tink!
column3: It isn't a big one, perhaps you may think, But it scattered the warriors quicker than wink Rink i tink, tink i tink, tink!

column2: Our Bilbil's a hero and so is his King; Our foemen have vanished like birds on the wing; I guess that as fighters we're quite the real thing Rink i tink, tink i tink, tink!
column3: Our Bilbil's a hero and so is his King; Our foemen have vanished like birds on the wing; I guess that as fighters we're quite the real thing Rink i tink, tink i tink, tink!

column2: Why don't you give a little credit to Inga? inquired the goat. If I remember aright, he did a little of the conquering himself.
column3: Why don't you give a little credit to Inga? inquired the goat. If I remember aright, he did a little of the conquering himself.

column2: So he did, responded the King, and that's the reason I'm sounding our own praise, Bilbil. Those who do the least, often shout the loudest and so get the most glory.
column3: So he did, responded the King, and that's the reason I'm sounding our own praise, Bilbil. Those who do the least, often shout the loudest and so get the most glory.

column2: Inga did so much that there is danger of his becoming more important than we are, and so we'd best say nothing about him.
column3: Inga did so much that there is danger of his becoming more important than we are, and so we'd best say nothing about him.

column2: When they reached the palace, which was an immense building, furnished throughout in regal splendor, Inga took formal possession and ordered the majordomo to show them the finest rooms the building contained.
column3: When they reached the palace, which was an immense building, furnished throughout in regal splendor, Inga took formal possession and ordered the majordomo to show them the finest rooms the building contained.

column2: There were many pleasant apartments, but Rinkitink proposed to Inga that they share one of the largest bedrooms together.
column3: There were many pleasant apartments, but Rinkitink proposed to Inga that they share one of the largest bedrooms together.

column2: For, said he, we are not sure that old Gos will not return and try to recapture his city, and you must remember that I have no magic to protect me.
column3: For, said he, we are not sure that old Gos will not return and try to recapture his city, and you must remember that I have no magic to protect me.

column2: In any danger, were I alone, I might be easily killed or captured, while if you are by my side you can save me from injury.
column3: In any danger, were I alone, I might be easily killed or captured, while if you are by my side you can save me from injury.

column3: King Rinkitink, said he, do you know what has become of my left shoe?

column3: Your shoe! exclaimed the King, giving a wide yawn and rubbing his eyes to get the sleep out of them. Have you lost a shoe?

column3: Yes, said Inga. I have searched everywhere in the room, and cannot find it.

column3: But why bother me about such a small thing? inquired Rinkitink. A shoe is only a shoe, and you can easily get another one. But, stay!

column3: Why, in the night, explained Rinkitink, sitting up and beginning to dress himself, I was wakened by the mewing of a cat that sat upon a wall of the palace, just outside my window.

column3: As the noise disturbed me, I reached out in the dark and caught up something and threw it at the cat, to frighten the creature away.

column3: I did not know what it was that I threw, and I was too sleepy to care; but probably it was your shoe, since it is now missing.

column3: Then, said the boy, in a despairing tone of voice, your carelessness has ruined me, as well as yourself, King Rinkitink, for in that shoe was concealed the magic power which protected us from danger.

column3: The King's face became very serious when he heard this and he uttered a low whistle of surprise and regret.

column2: Why on earth did you not warn me of this? he demanded. And why did you keep such a precious power in an old shoe? And why didn't you put the shoe under a pillow?

column2: You were very wrong, my lad, in not confiding to me, your faithful friend, the secret, for in that case the shoe would not now be lost.
column3: You were very wrong, my lad, in not confiding to me, your faithful friend, the secret, for in that case the shoe would not now be lost.

column3: After a half hour's careful search the boy said sorrowfully: Someone must have passed by, as we slept, and taken the precious shoe, not knowing its value.

column2: To us, King Rinkitink, this will be a dreadful misfortune, for we are surrounded by dangers from which we have now no protection.
column3: To us, King Rinkitink, this will be a dreadful misfortune, for we are surrounded by dangers from which we have now no protection.

column2: Luckily I have the other shoe left, within which is the magic power that gives me strength; so all is not lost.
column3: Luckily I have the other shoe left, within which is the magic power that gives me strength; so all is not lost.

column3: Then I advise you to get it at once, continued Rinkitink, for we can ill afford to lose the second shoe, as well as the one I threw at the cat.

column2: You are right! cried Inga, and they hastened back to their bedchamber.
column3: You are right! cried Inga, and they hastened back to their bedchamber.

column3: On entering the room they found an old woman sweeping and raising a great deal of dust.

column2: Where is my shoe? asked the Prince, anxiously.
column3: Where is my shoe? asked the Prince, anxiously.

column2: The old woman stopped sweeping and looked at him in a stupid way, for she was not very intelligent.
column3: The old woman stopped sweeping and looked at him in a stupid way, for she was not very intelligent.

column2: Do you mean the one odd shoe that was lying on the floor when I came in? she finally asked.

column3: Why, I threw it on the dust heap, outside the back gate, said she, for, it being but a single shoe, with no mate, it can be of no use to anyone.

column3: Show us the way to the dust heap at once! commanded the boy, sternly, for he was greatly frightened by this new misfortune which threatened him.

column2: The old woman hobbled away and they followed her, constantly urging her to hasten; but when they reached the dust heap no shoe was to be seen.
column3: The old woman hobbled away and they followed her, constantly urging her to hasten; but when they reached the dust heap no shoe was to be seen.

column2: This is terrible! wailed the young Prince, ready to weep at his loss.
column3: This is terrible! wailed the young Prince, ready to weep at his loss.

column2: We are now absolutely ruined, and at the mercy of our enemies. Nor shall I be able to liberate my dear father and mother.
column3: We are now absolutely ruined, and at the mercy of our enemies. Nor shall I be able to liberate my dear father and mother.

column3: I believe, Inga, we must now depend upon our wits to get us out of the scrape we are in.

column3: being deep in thought as to the strange manner in which the powerful King Gos and his city had been conquered by a boy Prince who had come from Pingaree.

column3: Soon after, on turning a corner of the wall, Nikobob came to a dust heap where, lying amidst a mass of rubbish, was another shoe the mate to the one he had before found.

column2: The charcoal burner, however, knew the wild forest well, and especially this part of it lying between the city and his home.
column3: The charcoal burner, however, knew the wild forest well, and especially this part of it lying between the city and his home.

column2: It was the favorite haunt of the ferocious beast Choggenmugger, dreaded by every dweller in the Island of Regos. Choggenmugger was so old that everyone thought it must have been there since the world was made,
column3: It was the favorite haunt of the ferocious beast Choggenmugger, dreaded by every dweller in the Island of Regos. Choggenmugger was so old that everyone thought it must have been there since the world was made,

column2: and each year of its life the huge scales that covered its body grew thicker and harder and its jaws grew wider and its teeth grew sharper and its appetite grew more keen than ever.
column3: and each year of its life the huge scales that covered its body grew thicker and harder and its jaws grew wider and its teeth grew sharper and its appetite grew more keen than ever.

column2: In former ages there had been many dragons in Regos, but Choggenmugger was so fond of dragons that he had eaten all of them long ago.
column3: In former ages there had been many dragons in Regos, but Choggenmugger was so fond of dragons that he had eaten all of them long ago.

column2: There had also been great serpents and crocodiles in the forest marshes, but all had gone to feed the hunger of Choggenmugger.

column2: Then Nikobob gave himself up for lost and his heart almost ceased to beat.
column3: Then Nikobob gave himself up for lost and his heart almost ceased to beat.

column3: So he raised his ax and brought it down upon the red, protruding tongue of the monster and cut it clean off!

column3: Nikobob took off his coat, to give himself more freedom of action, and then he earnestly renewed the attack. But now the ax seemed blunted by the hard scales and made no impression upon them whatever.

column3: The creature advanced with glaring, wicked eyes, and Nikobob seized his coat under his arm and turned to flee.

column3: Finding himself uninjured, Nikobob put on his coat, again seized his ax, and in a short time had chopped Choggenmugger into many small pieces a task that proved not only easy but very agreeable.

column2: I must be the strongest man in all the world! thought the charcoal burner, as he proudly resumed his way, for Choggenmugger has been the terror of Regos since the world began,

column3: He met no further adventure and at midday reached a little clearing in the forest where stood his humble cabin.

column2: Great news! I have great news for you, he shouted, as his wife and little daughter came to greet him. King Gos has been conquered by a boy Prince from the far island of Pingaree,
column3: Great news! I have great news for you, he shouted, as his wife and little daughter came to greet him. King Gos has been conquered by a boy Prince from the far island of Pingaree,

column3: and I have this day unaided destroyed Choggenmugger by the might of my strong arm.

column3: This was, indeed, great news. They brought Nikobob into the house and set him in an easy chair and made him tell everything he knew about the Prince of Pingaree and the fat King of Gilgad,

column3: With this he drew the shoes from the pocket of his coat and handed them to Zella, who gave him a dozen kisses in payment and was much pleased with her gift.

column3: When she tried them on her feet, they fitted as well as if made for her.

column3: When Zella and her mother were not working in the cabin, cooking or sewing, they often searched the neighboring forest for honey which the wild bees cleverly hid in hollow trees.

column3: The day after Nikobob's return, as they were starting out after honey, Zella decided to put on her new shoes, as they would keep the twigs that covered the ground from hurting her feet.

column2: So she danced along, very happily, followed by her mother, and presently they came to a tree in which was a deep hollow. Zella thrust her hand and arm into the space and found that the tree was full of honey,
column3: So she danced along, very happily, followed by her mother, and presently they came to a tree in which was a deep hollow. Zella thrust her hand and arm into the space and found that the tree was full of honey,

column3: so she began to dig it out with a wooden paddle.

column2: Her mother, who held the pail, suddenly cried in warning: Look out, Zella; the bees are coming! and then the good woman ran fast toward the house to escape.
column3: Her mother, who held the pail, suddenly cried in warning: Look out, Zella; the bees are coming! and then the good woman ran fast toward the house to escape.

column2: Zella, however, had no more than time to turn her head when a thick swarm of bees surrounded her, angry because they had caught her stealing their honey and intent on stinging the girl as a punishment.
column3: Zella, however, had no more than time to turn her head when a thick swarm of bees surrounded her, angry because they had caught her stealing their honey and intent on stinging the girl as a punishment.

column2: She knew her danger and expected to be badly injured by the multitude of stinging bees, but to her surprise the little creatures were unable to fly close enough to her to stick their dart like stingers into her flesh.
column3: She knew her danger and expected to be badly injured by the multitude of stinging bees, but to her surprise the little creatures were unable to fly close enough to her to stick their dart like stingers into her flesh.

column3: They swarmed about her in a dark cloud, and their angry buzzing was terrible to hear, yet the little girl remained unharmed.

column3: When she realized this, Zella was no longer afraid but continued to ladle out the honey until she had secured all that was in the tree.

column2: Then she returned to the cabin, where her mother was weeping and bemoaning the fate of her darling child, and the good woman was greatly astonished to find Zella had escaped injury.
column3: Then she returned to the cabin, where her mother was weeping and bemoaning the fate of her darling child, and the good woman was greatly astonished to find Zella had escaped injury.

column2: Again they went to the woods to search for honey, and although the mother always ran away whenever the bees came near them, Zella paid no attention to the creatures but kept at her work,
column3: Again they went to the woods to search for honey, and although the mother always ran away whenever the bees came near them, Zella paid no attention to the creatures but kept at her work,

column2: so that before supper time came the pails were again filled to overflowing with delicious honey.
column3: so that before supper time came the pails were again filled to overflowing with delicious honey.

column2: With such good fortune as we have had this day, said her mother, we shall soon gather enough honey for you to carry to Queen Cor.
column3: With such good fortune as we have had this day, said her mother, we shall soon gather enough honey for you to carry to Queen Cor.

column2: For it seems the wicked Queen was very fond of honey and it had been Zella's custom to go, once every year, to the City of Coregos, to carry the Queen a supply of sweet honey for her table.
column3: For it seems the wicked Queen was very fond of honey and it had been Zella's custom to go, once every year, to the City of Coregos, to carry the Queen a supply of sweet honey for her table.

column3: But now, said Zella, I shall be able to carry two pailsful to the Queen, who will, I am sure, give me a good price for it.

column2: True, answered her mother, and, as the boy Prince may take it into his head to conquer Coregos, as well as Regos, I think it best for you to start on your journey to Queen Cor tomorrow morning.
column3: True, answered her mother, and, as the boy Prince may take it into his head to conquer Coregos, as well as Regos, I think it best for you to start on your journey to Queen Cor tomorrow morning.

column2: Do you not agree with me, Nikobob? she added, turning to her husband, the charcoal burner, who was eating his supper.
column3: Do you not agree with me, Nikobob? she added, turning to her husband, the charcoal burner, who was eating his supper.

column2: I agree with you, he replied. If Zella must go to the City of Coregos, she may as well start to morrow morning.

column2: Rinkitink in oz by L Frank Baum. Chapter Ten The Cunning of Queen Cor.

column2: You may be sure the Queen of Coregos was not well pleased to have King Gos and all his warriors living in her city after they had fled from their own.
column3: You may be sure the Queen of Coregos was not well pleased to have King Gos and all his warriors living in her city after they had fled from their own.

column2: They were savage natured and quarrelsome men at all times, and their tempers had not improved since their conquest by the Prince of Pingaree.
column3: They were savage natured and quarrelsome men at all times, and their tempers had not improved since their conquest by the Prince of Pingaree.

column2: Moreover, they were eating up Queen Cor's provisions and crowding the houses of her own people, who grumbled and complained until their Queen was heartily tired.
column3: Moreover, they were eating up Queen Cor's provisions and crowding the houses of her own people, who grumbled and complained until their Queen was heartily tired.

column2: Shame on you! she said to her husband, King Gos, to be driven out of your city by a boy, a roly poly King and a billy goat! Why do you not go back and fight them?
column3: Shame on you! she said to her husband, King Gos, to be driven out of your city by a boy, a roly poly King and a billy goat! Why do you not go back and fight them?

column2: No human can fight against the powers of magic, returned the King in a surly voice. That boy is either a fairy or under the protection of fairies.
column3: No human can fight against the powers of magic, returned the King in a surly voice. That boy is either a fairy or under the protection of fairies.

column2: We escaped with our lives only because we were quick to run away; but, should we return to Regos, the same terrible power that burst open the city gates would crush us all to atoms.
column3: We escaped with our lives only because we were quick to run away; but, should we return to Regos, the same terrible power that burst open the city gates would crush us all to atoms.

column2: Bah! you are a coward, cried the Queen, tauntingly.
column3: Bah! you are a coward, cried the Queen, tauntingly.

column2: I am not a coward, said the big King. I have killed in battle scores of my enemies; by the might of my sword and my good right arm I have conquered many nations;
column3: I am not a coward, said the big King. I have killed in battle scores of my enemies; by the might of my sword and my good right arm I have conquered many nations;

column2: all my life people have feared me.
column3: all my life people have feared me.

column2: But no one would dare face the tremendous power of the Prince of Pingaree, boy though he is. It would not be courage, it would be folly, to attempt it.
column3: But no one would dare face the tremendous power of the Prince of Pingaree, boy though he is. It would not be courage, it would be folly, to attempt it.

column2: Then meet his power with cunning, suggested the Queen. Take my advice, and steal over to Regos at night, when it is dark, and capture or destroy the boy while he sleeps.
column3: Then meet his power with cunning, suggested the Queen. Take my advice, and steal over to Regos at night, when it is dark, and capture or destroy the boy while he sleeps.

column2: No weapon can touch his body, was the answer. He bears a charmed life and cannot be injured.
column3: No weapon can touch his body, was the answer. He bears a charmed life and cannot be injured.

column2: Does the fat King possess magic powers, or the goat? inquired Cor.
column3: Does the fat King possess magic powers, or the goat? inquired Cor.

column2: I think not, said Gos. We could not injure them, indeed, any more than we could the boy, but they did not seem to have any unusual strength, although the goat's head is harder than a battering ram.
column3: I think not, said Gos. We could not injure them, indeed, any more than we could the boy, but they did not seem to have any unusual strength, although the goat's head is harder than a battering ram.

column2: Well, mused the Queen, there is surely some way to conquer that slight boy. If you are afraid to undertake the job, I shall go myself.
column3: Well, mused the Queen, there is surely some way to conquer that slight boy. If you are afraid to undertake the job, I shall go myself.

column2: By some stratagem I shall manage to make him my prisoner. He will not dare to defy a Queen, and no magic can stand against a woman's cunning.
column3: By some stratagem I shall manage to make him my prisoner. He will not dare to defy a Queen, and no magic can stand against a woman's cunning.

column2: Go ahead, if you like, replied the King, with an evil grin, and if you are hung up by the thumbs or cast into a dungeon, it will serve you right for thinking you can succeed where a skilled warrior dares not make the attempt.
column3: Go ahead, if you like, replied the King, with an evil grin, and if you are hung up by the thumbs or cast into a dungeon, it will serve you right for thinking you can succeed where a skilled warrior dares not make the attempt.

column2: I'm not afraid, answered the Queen. It is only soldiers and bullies who are cowards.
column3: I'm not afraid, answered the Queen. It is only soldiers and bullies who are cowards.

column2: In spite of this assertion, Queen Cor was not so brave as she was cunning. For several days she thought over this plan and that, and tried to decide which was most likely to succeed.
column3: In spite of this assertion, Queen Cor was not so brave as she was cunning. For several days she thought over this plan and that, and tried to decide which was most likely to succeed.

column2: She had never seen the boy Prince but had heard so many tales of him from the defeated warriors, and especially from Captain Buzzub, that she had learned to respect his power.
column3: She had never seen the boy Prince but had heard so many tales of him from the defeated warriors, and especially from Captain Buzzub, that she had learned to respect his power.

column2: Spurred on by the knowledge that she would never get rid of her unwelcome guests until Prince Inga was overcome and Regos regained for King Gos,
column3: Spurred on by the knowledge that she would never get rid of her unwelcome guests until Prince Inga was overcome and Regos regained for King Gos,

column2: the Queen of Coregos finally decided to trust to luck and her native wit to defeat a simple minded boy, however powerful he might be.
column3: the Queen of Coregos finally decided to trust to luck and her native wit to defeat a simple minded boy, however powerful he might be.

column2: Inga could not suspect what she was going to do, because she did not know herself. She intended to act boldly and trust to chance to win.
column3: Inga could not suspect what she was going to do, because she did not know herself. She intended to act boldly and trust to chance to win.

column2: It is evident that had the cunning Queen known that Inga had lost all his magic, she would not have devoted so much time to the simple matter of capturing him,
column3: It is evident that had the cunning Queen known that Inga had lost all his magic, she would not have devoted so much time to the simple matter of capturing him,

column2: but like all others she was impressed by the marvelous exhibition of power he had shown in capturing Regos, and had no reason to believe the boy was less powerful now.
column3: but like all others she was impressed by the marvelous exhibition of power he had shown in capturing Regos, and had no reason to believe the boy was less powerful now.

column2: One morning Queen Cor boldly entered a boat, and, taking four men with her as an escort and bodyguard, was rowed across the narrow channel to Regos.
column3: One morning Queen Cor boldly entered a boat, and, taking four men with her as an escort and bodyguard, was rowed across the narrow channel to Regos.

column2: Prince Inga was sitting in the palace playing checkers with King Rinkitink when a servant came to him, saying that Queen Cor had arrived and desired an audience with him.
column3: Prince Inga was sitting in the palace playing checkers with King Rinkitink when a servant came to him, saying that Queen Cor had arrived and desired an audience with him.

column2: With many misgivings lest the wicked Queen discover that he had now lost his magic powers, the boy ordered her to be admitted, and she soon entered the room and bowed low before him, in mock respect.
column3: With many misgivings lest the wicked Queen discover that he had now lost his magic powers, the boy ordered her to be admitted, and she soon entered the room and bowed low before him, in mock respect.

column2: Cor was a big woman, almost as tall as King Gos. She had flashing black eyes and the dark complexion you see on gypsies. Her temper, when irritated,
column3: Cor was a big woman, almost as tall as King Gos. She had flashing black eyes and the dark complexion you see on gypsies. Her temper, when irritated,

column2: was something dreadful, and her face wore an evil expression which she tried to cover by smiling sweetly often when she meant the most mischief.
column3: was something dreadful, and her face wore an evil expression which she tried to cover by smiling sweetly often when she meant the most mischief.

column2: I have come, said she in a low voice, to render homage to the noble Prince of Pingaree. I am told that Your Highness is the strongest person in the world,
column3: I have come, said she in a low voice, to render homage to the noble Prince of Pingaree. I am told that Your Highness is the strongest person in the world,

column2: and invincible in battle, and therefore I wish you to become my friend, rather than my enemy.
column3: and invincible in battle, and therefore I wish you to become my friend, rather than my enemy.

column2: While the men were tearing away the bridge of boats the Queen ran up to the palace of Gos, where she met her husband.
column3: While the men were tearing away the bridge of boats the Queen ran up to the palace of Gos, where she met her husband.

column2: That boy is a wizard! she gasped. There is no standing against him.
column3: That boy is a wizard! she gasped. There is no standing against him.

column2: Oh, have you discovered his magic at last? replied Gos, laughing in her face. Who, now, is the coward?
column3: Oh, have you discovered his magic at last? replied Gos, laughing in her face. Who, now, is the coward?

column2: Don't laugh! cried Queen Cor. It is no laughing matter. Both our islands are as good as conquered, this very minute. What shall we do, Gos?
column3: Don't laugh! cried Queen Cor. It is no laughing matter. Both our islands are as good as conquered, this very minute. What shall we do, Gos?

column2: Come in, he said, growing serious, and let us talk it over.
column3: Come in, he said, growing serious, and let us talk it over.

column2: So they went into a room of the palace and talked long and earnestly.
column3: So they went into a room of the palace and talked long and earnestly.

column2: The boy intends to liberate his father and mother, and all the people of Pingaree, and to take them back to their island, said Cor.
column3: The boy intends to liberate his father and mother, and all the people of Pingaree, and to take them back to their island, said Cor.

column2: He may also destroy our palaces and make us his slaves. I can see but one way, Gos, to prevent him from doing all this, and whatever else he pleases to do.
column3: He may also destroy our palaces and make us his slaves. I can see but one way, Gos, to prevent him from doing all this, and whatever else he pleases to do.

column2: What way is that? asked King Gos.
column3: What way is that? asked King Gos.

column2: We must take the boy's parents away from here as quickly as possible.
column3: We must take the boy's parents away from here as quickly as possible.

column2: I have with me the Queen of Pingaree, and you can run up to the mines and get the King. Then we will carry them away in a boat and hide them where the boy cannot find them, with all his magic.
column3: I have with me the Queen of Pingaree, and you can run up to the mines and get the King. Then we will carry them away in a boat and hide them where the boy cannot find them, with all his magic.

column2: We will use the King and Queen of Pingaree as hostages, and send word to the boy wizard that if he does not go away from our islands and allow us to rule them undisturbed,
column3: We will use the King and Queen of Pingaree as hostages, and send word to the boy wizard that if he does not go away from our islands and allow us to rule them undisturbed,

column2: in our own way, we will put his father and mother to death.
column3: in our own way, we will put his father and mother to death.

column2: Also we will say that as long as we are let alone his parents will be safe, although still safely hidden. I believe, Gos, that in this way we can compel Prince Ingato obey us,
column3: Also we will say that as long as we are let alone his parents will be safe, although still safely hidden. I believe, Gos, that in this way we can compel Prince Ingato obey us,

column2: for he seems very fond of his parents.
column3: for he seems very fond of his parents.

column2: It isn't a bad idea, said Gos, reflectively; but where can we hide the King and Queen, so that the boy cannot find them?
column3: It isn't a bad idea, said Gos, reflectively; but where can we hide the King and Queen, so that the boy cannot find them?

column2: In the country of the Nome King, on the mainland away at the south, she replied. The nomes are our friends, and they possess magic powers that will enable them to protect the prisoners from discovery.
column3: In the country of the Nome King, on the mainland away at the south, she replied. The nomes are our friends, and they possess magic powers that will enable them to protect the prisoners from discovery.

column2: If we can manage to get the King and Queen of Pingaree to the Nome Kingdom before the boy knows what we are doing, I am sure our plot will succeed.
column3: If we can manage to get the King and Queen of Pingaree to the Nome Kingdom before the boy knows what we are doing, I am sure our plot will succeed.

column2: Gos gave the plan considerable thought in the next five minutes, and the more he thought about it the more clever and reasonable it seemed.
column3: Gos gave the plan considerable thought in the next five minutes, and the more he thought about it the more clever and reasonable it seemed.

column2: So he agreed to do as Queen Cor suggested and at once hurried away to the mines, where he arrived before Prince Inga did. The next morning he carried King Kitticut back to Regos.
column3: So he agreed to do as Queen Cor suggested and at once hurried away to the mines, where he arrived before Prince Inga did. The next morning he carried King Kitticut back to Regos.

column2: While Gos was gone, Queen Cor busied herself in preparing a large and swift boat for the journey. She placed in it several bags of gold and jewels with which to bribe the nomes,
column3: While Gos was gone, Queen Cor busied herself in preparing a large and swift boat for the journey. She placed in it several bags of gold and jewels with which to bribe the nomes,

column2: and selected forty of the strongest oarsmen in Regos to row the boat.
column3: and selected forty of the strongest oarsmen in Regos to row the boat.

column2: The instant King Gos returned with his royal prisoner all was ready for departure.
column3: The instant King Gos returned with his royal prisoner all was ready for departure.

column2: They quickly entered the boat with their two important captives and without a word of explanation to any of their people they commanded the oarsmen to start,
column3: They quickly entered the boat with their two important captives and without a word of explanation to any of their people they commanded the oarsmen to start,

column2: and were soon out of sight upon the broad expanse of the Nonestic Ocean.
column3: and were soon out of sight upon the broad expanse of the Nonestic Ocean.

column2: Inga arrived at the city some hours later and was much distressed when he learned that his father and mother had been spirited away from the islands.
column3: Inga arrived at the city some hours later and was much distressed when he learned that his father and mother had been spirited away from the islands.

column2: I shall follow them, of course, said the boy to Rinkitink, and if I cannot overtake them on the ocean I will search the world over until I find them.
column3: I shall follow them, of course, said the boy to Rinkitink, and if I cannot overtake them on the ocean I will search the world over until I find them.

column2: But before I leave here I must arrange to send our people back to Pingaree.
column3: But before I leave here I must arrange to send our people back to Pingaree.

column2: End of chapter Fifteen.
column3: End of chapter Fifteen.

column2: Almost the first persons that Zella saw when she landed from the silver lined boat at Regos were her father and mother.
column3: Almost the first persons that Zella saw when she landed from the silver lined boat at Regos were her father and mother.

column2: Nikobob and his wife had been greatly worried when their little daughter failed to return from Coregos,
column3: Nikobob and his wife had been greatly worried when their little daughter failed to return from Coregos,

column2: so they had set out to discover what had become of her.
column3: so they had set out to discover what had become of her.

column2: When they reached the City of Regos, that very morning, they were astonished to hear news of all the strange events that had taken place; still,
column3: When they reached the City of Regos, that very morning, they were astonished to hear news of all the strange events that had taken place; still,

column2: they found comfort when told that Zella had been seen in the boat of Prince Inga, which had gone to the north.
column3: they found comfort when told that Zella had been seen in the boat of Prince Inga, which had gone to the north.

column2: Then, while they wondered what this could mean, the silver lined boat appeared again, with their daughter in it, and they ran down to the shore to give her a welcome and many joyful kisses.
column3: Then, while they wondered what this could mean, the silver lined boat appeared again, with their daughter in it, and they ran down to the shore to give her a welcome and many joyful kisses.

column2: Inga invited the good people to the palace of King Gos, where he conferred with them, as well as with Rinkitink and Bilbil.
column3: Inga invited the good people to the palace of King Gos, where he conferred with them, as well as with Rinkitink and Bilbil.

column2: Now that the King and Queen of Regos and Coregos have run away, he said, there is no one to rule these islands. So it is my duty to appoint a new ruler,
column3: Now that the King and Queen of Regos and Coregos have run away, he said, there is no one to rule these islands. So it is my duty to appoint a new ruler,

column2: and as Nikobob, Zella's father, is an honest and worthy man, I shall make him the King of the Twin Islands.
column3: and as Nikobob, Zella's father, is an honest and worthy man, I shall make him the King of the Twin Islands.

column2: Me? cried Nikobob, astounded by this speech. I beg Your Highness, on my bended knees, not to do so cruel a thing as to make me King!
column3: Me? cried Nikobob, astounded by this speech. I beg Your Highness, on my bended knees, not to do so cruel a thing as to make me King!

column2: Why not? inquired Rinkitink. I'm a King, and I know how it feels. I assure you, good Nikobob, that I quite enjoy my high rank, although a jeweled crown is rather heavy to wear in hot weather.
column3: Why not? inquired Rinkitink. I'm a King, and I know how it feels. I assure you, good Nikobob, that I quite enjoy my high rank, although a jeweled crown is rather heavy to wear in hot weather.

column2: With you, noble sir, it is different, said Nikobob, for you are far from your kingdom and its trials and worries and may do as you please.
column3: With you, noble sir, it is different, said Nikobob, for you are far from your kingdom and its trials and worries and may do as you please.

column2: But to remain in Regos, as King over these fierce and unruly warriors, would be to live in constant anxiety and peril, and the chances are that they would murder me within a month.
column3: But to remain in Regos, as King over these fierce and unruly warriors, would be to live in constant anxiety and peril, and the chances are that they would murder me within a month.

column2: As I have done no harm to anyone and have tried to be a good and upright man, I do not think that I should be condemned to such a dreadful fate.
column3: As I have done no harm to anyone and have tried to be a good and upright man, I do not think that I should be condemned to such a dreadful fate.

column2: Very well, replied Inga, we will say no more about your being King.
column3: Very well, replied Inga, we will say no more about your being King.

column2: I merely wanted to make you rich and prosperous, as I had promised Zella.
column3: I merely wanted to make you rich and prosperous, as I had promised Zella.

column2: Please forget that promise, pleaded the charcoal burner, earnestly; I have been safe from molestation for many years, because I was poor and possessed nothing that anyone else could envy.
column3: Please forget that promise, pleaded the charcoal burner, earnestly; I have been safe from molestation for many years, because I was poor and possessed nothing that anyone else could envy.

column2: But if you make me rich and prosperous I shall at once become the prey of thieves and marauders and probably will lose my life in the attempt to protect my fortune.
column3: But if you make me rich and prosperous I shall at once become the prey of thieves and marauders and probably will lose my life in the attempt to protect my fortune.

column2: Inga looked at the man in surprise.
column3: Inga looked at the man in surprise.

column2: What, then, can I do to please you? he inquired.
column3: What, then, can I do to please you? he inquired.

column2: Nothing more than to allow me to go home to my poor cabin, said Nikobob.
column3: Nothing more than to allow me to go home to my poor cabin, said Nikobob.

column2: Perhaps, remarked King Rinkitink, the charcoal burner has more wisdom concealed in that hard head of his than we gave him credit for.
column3: Perhaps, remarked King Rinkitink, the charcoal burner has more wisdom concealed in that hard head of his than we gave him credit for.

column2: But let us use that wisdom, for the present, to counsel us what to do in this emergency.
column3: But let us use that wisdom, for the present, to counsel us what to do in this emergency.

column2: What you call my wisdom, said Nikobob, is merely common sense. I have noticed that some men become rich, and are scorned by some and robbed by others.
column3: What you call my wisdom, said Nikobob, is merely common sense. I have noticed that some men become rich, and are scorned by some and robbed by others.

column2: Other men become famous, and are mocked at and derided by their fellows.
column3: Other men become famous, and are mocked at and derided by their fellows.

column2: But the poor and humble man who lives unnoticed and unknown escapes all these troubles and is the only one who can appreciate the joy of living.
column3: But the poor and humble man who lives unnoticed and unknown escapes all these troubles and is the only one who can appreciate the joy of living.

column2: If I had a hand, instead of a cloven hoof, I'd like to shake hands with you, Nikobob, said Bilbil the goat. But the poor man must not have a cruel master, or he is undone.
column3: If I had a hand, instead of a cloven hoof, I'd like to shake hands with you, Nikobob, said Bilbil the goat. But the poor man must not have a cruel master, or he is undone.

column2: During the council they found, indeed, that the advice of the charcoal burner was both shrewd and sensible, and they profited much by his words.
column3: During the council they found, indeed, that the advice of the charcoal burner was both shrewd and sensible, and they profited much by his words.

column2: Inga gave Captain Buzzub the command of the warriors and made him promise to keep his men quiet and orderly if he could. Then the boy allowed all of King Gos's former slaves,
column3: Inga gave Captain Buzzub the command of the warriors and made him promise to keep his men quiet and orderly if he could. Then the boy allowed all of King Gos's former slaves,

column2: except those who came from Pingaree, to choose what boats they required and to stock them with provisions and row away to their own countries.
column3: except those who came from Pingaree, to choose what boats they required and to stock them with provisions and row away to their own countries.

column2: When these had departed, with grateful thanks and many blessings showered upon the boy Prince who had set them free, Inga made preparations to send his own people home,
column3: When these had departed, with grateful thanks and many blessings showered upon the boy Prince who had set them free, Inga made preparations to send his own people home,

column2: where they were told to rebuild their houses and then erect a new royal palace.
column3: where they were told to rebuild their houses and then erect a new royal palace.

column2: They were then to await patiently the coming of King Kitticut or Prince Inga.
column3: They were then to await patiently the coming of King Kitticut or Prince Inga.

column2: My greatest worry, said the boy to his friends, is to know whom to appoint to take charge of this work of restoring Pingaree to its former condition.
column3: My greatest worry, said the boy to his friends, is to know whom to appoint to take charge of this work of restoring Pingaree to its former condition.

column2: My men are all pearl fishers, and although willing and honest, have no talent for directing others how to work.
column3: My men are all pearl fishers, and although willing and honest, have no talent for directing others how to work.

column2: While the preparations for departure were being made, Nikobob offered to direct the men of Pingaree, and did so in a very capable manner.
column3: While the preparations for departure were being made, Nikobob offered to direct the men of Pingaree, and did so in a very capable manner.

column2: As the island had been despoiled of all its valuable furniture and draperies and rich cloths and paintings and statuary and the like, as well as gold and silver and ornaments,
column3: As the island had been despoiled of all its valuable furniture and draperies and rich cloths and paintings and statuary and the like, as well as gold and silver and ornaments,

column2: Inga thought it no more than just that they be replaced by the spoilers.
column3: Inga thought it no more than just that they be replaced by the spoilers.

column2: So he directed his people to search through the storehouses of King Gos and to regain all their goods and chattels that could be found.
column3: So he directed his people to search through the storehouses of King Gos and to regain all their goods and chattels that could be found.

column2: Also he instructed them to take as much else as they required to make their new homes comfortable,
column3: Also he instructed them to take as much else as they required to make their new homes comfortable,

column2: so that many boats were loaded full of goods that would enable the people to restore Pingaree to its former state of comfort.
column3: so that many boats were loaded full of goods that would enable the people to restore Pingaree to its former state of comfort.

column2: For his father's new palace the boy plundered the palaces of both Queen Cor and King Gos,
column3: For his father's new palace the boy plundered the palaces of both Queen Cor and King Gos,

column2: sending enough wares away with his people to make King Kitticut's new residence as handsomely fitted and furnished as had been the one which the ruthless invaders from Regos had destroyed.
column3: sending enough wares away with his people to make King Kitticut's new residence as handsomely fitted and furnished as had been the one which the ruthless invaders from Regos had destroyed.

column2: It was a great fleet of boats that set out one bright, sunny morning on the voyage to Pingaree, carrying all the men, women and children and all the goods for refitting their homes.
column3: It was a great fleet of boats that set out one bright, sunny morning on the voyage to Pingaree, carrying all the men, women and children and all the goods for refitting their homes.

column2: As he saw the fleet depart, Prince Inga felt that he had already successfully accomplished a part of his mission,
column3: As he saw the fleet depart, Prince Inga felt that he had already successfully accomplished a part of his mission,

column2: but he vowed he would never return to Pingaree in person until he could take his father and mother there with him;
column3: but he vowed he would never return to Pingaree in person until he could take his father and mother there with him;

column2: unless, indeed, King Gos wickedly destroyed his beloved parents, in which case Inga would become the King of Pingaree and it would be his duty to go to his people and rule over them.
column3: unless, indeed, King Gos wickedly destroyed his beloved parents, in which case Inga would become the King of Pingaree and it would be his duty to go to his people and rule over them.

column2: It was while the last of the boats were preparing to sail for Pingaree that Nikobob, who had been of great service in getting them ready, came to Inga in a thoughtful mood and said:
column3: It was while the last of the boats were preparing to sail for Pingaree that Nikobob, who had been of great service in getting them ready, came to Inga in a thoughtful mood and said:

column2: Your Highness, my wife and my daughter Zella have been urging me to leave Regos and settle down in your island, in a new home.
column3: Your Highness, my wife and my daughter Zella have been urging me to leave Regos and settle down in your island, in a new home.

column2: From what your people have told me, Pingaree is a better place to live than Regos, and there are no cruel warriors or savage beasts there to keep one in constant fear for the safety of those he loves.
column3: From what your people have told me, Pingaree is a better place to live than Regos, and there are no cruel warriors or savage beasts there to keep one in constant fear for the safety of those he loves.

column2: Therefore, I have come to ask to go with my family in one of the boats.
column3: Therefore, I have come to ask to go with my family in one of the boats.

column2: Inga was much pleased with this proposal and not only granted Nikobob permission to go to Pingaree to live, but instructed him to take with him sufficient goods to furnish his new home in a comfortable manner.
column3: Inga was much pleased with this proposal and not only granted Nikobob permission to go to Pingaree to live, but instructed him to take with him sufficient goods to furnish his new home in a comfortable manner.

column2: In addition to this, he appointed Nikobob general manager of the buildings and of the pearl fisheries, until his father or he himself arrived,
column3: In addition to this, he appointed Nikobob general manager of the buildings and of the pearl fisheries, until his father or he himself arrived,

column2: and the people approved this order because they liked Nikobob and knew him to be just and honest.
column3: and the people approved this order because they liked Nikobob and knew him to be just and honest.

column2: Soon as the last boat of the great flotilla had disappeared from the view of those left at Regos, Inga and Rinkitink prepared to leave the island themselves.
column3: Soon as the last boat of the great flotilla had disappeared from the view of those left at Regos, Inga and Rinkitink prepared to leave the island themselves.

column2: The boy was anxious to overtake the boat of King Gos, if possible, and Rinkitink had no desire to remain in Regos.
column3: The boy was anxious to overtake the boat of King Gos, if possible, and Rinkitink had no desire to remain in Regos.

column2: Buzzub and the warriors stood silently on the shore and watched the black boat with its silver lining depart,
column3: Buzzub and the warriors stood silently on the shore and watched the black boat with its silver lining depart,
