column3: and I am sure they were as glad to be rid of their unwelcome visitors as Inga and Rinkitink and Bilbil were to leave.

column2: The boy asked the White Pearl what direction the boat of King Gos had taken and then he followed after it, rowing hard and steadily for eight days without becoming at all weary.
column3: The boy asked the White Pearl what direction the boat of King Gos had taken and then he followed after it, rowing hard and steadily for eight days without becoming at all weary.

column2: The Kingdom of the Nomes does not border on the Nonestic Ocean, from which it is separated by the Kingdom of Rinkitink and the Country of the Wheelers,
column3: The Kingdom of the Nomes does not border on the Nonestic Ocean, from which it is separated by the Kingdom of Rinkitink and the Country of the Wheelers,

column2: which is a part of the Land of Ev.
column3: which is a part of the Land of Ev.

column2: Rinkitink's country is separated from the country of the Nomes by a row of high and steep mountains, from which it extends to the sea.
column3: Rinkitink's country is separated from the country of the Nomes by a row of high and steep mountains, from which it extends to the sea.

column2: The Country of the Wheelers is a sandy waste that is open on one side to the Nonestic Ocean and on the other side has no barrier to separate it from the Nome Country,
column3: The Country of the Wheelers is a sandy waste that is open on one side to the Nonestic Ocean and on the other side has no barrier to separate it from the Nome Country,

column2: therefore it was on the coast of the Wheelers that King Cos landed in a spot quite deserted by any of the curious inhabitants of that country.
column3: therefore it was on the coast of the Wheelers that King Cos landed in a spot quite deserted by any of the curious inhabitants of that country.

column2: The Nome Country is very large in extent, and is only separated from the Land of Oz, on its eastern borders, by a Deadly Desert that can not be crossed by mortals,
column3: The Nome Country is very large in extent, and is only separated from the Land of Oz, on its eastern borders, by a Deadly Desert that can not be crossed by mortals,

column2: unless they are aided by the fairies or by magic.
column3: unless they are aided by the fairies or by magic.

column2: The nomes are a numerous and mischievous people, living in underground caverns of wide extent, connected one with another by arches and passages.
column3: The nomes are a numerous and mischievous people, living in underground caverns of wide extent, connected one with another by arches and passages.

column2: The word nome means one who knows, and these people are so called because they know where all the gold and silver and precious stones are hidden in the earth a knowledge that no other living creatures share with them.
column3: The word nome means one who knows, and these people are so called because they know where all the gold and silver and precious stones are hidden in the earth a knowledge that no other living creatures share with them.

column2: The nomes are busy people, constantly digging up gold in one place and taking it to another place, where they secretly bury it, and perhaps this is the reason they alone know where to find it.
column3: The nomes are busy people, constantly digging up gold in one place and taking it to another place, where they secretly bury it, and perhaps this is the reason they alone know where to find it.

column2: The nomes were ruled, at the time of which I write, by a King named Kaliko.
column3: The nomes were ruled, at the time of which I write, by a King named Kaliko.

column2: King Gos had expected to be pursued by Inga in his magic boat, so he made all the haste possible, urging his forty rowers to their best efforts night and day.
column3: King Gos had expected to be pursued by Inga in his magic boat, so he made all the haste possible, urging his forty rowers to their best efforts night and day.

column2: To his joy he was not overtaken but landed on the sandy beach of the Wheelers on the morning of the eighth day.
column3: To his joy he was not overtaken but landed on the sandy beach of the Wheelers on the morning of the eighth day.

column2: The forty rowers were left with the boat, while Queen Cor and King Cos, with their royal prisoners, who were still chained, began the journey to the Nome King.
column3: The forty rowers were left with the boat, while Queen Cor and King Cos, with their royal prisoners, who were still chained, began the journey to the Nome King.

column2: It was not long before they passed the sands and reached the rocky country belonging to the nomes, but they were still a long way from the entrance to the underground caverns in which lived the Nome King.
column3: It was not long before they passed the sands and reached the rocky country belonging to the nomes, but they were still a long way from the entrance to the underground caverns in which lived the Nome King.

column2: There was a dim path, winding between stones and boulders, over which the walking was quite difficult, especially as the path led up hills that were small mountains,
column3: There was a dim path, winding between stones and boulders, over which the walking was quite difficult, especially as the path led up hills that were small mountains,

column2: and then down steep and abrupt slopes where any misstep might mean a broken leg.
column3: and then down steep and abrupt slopes where any misstep might mean a broken leg.

column2: Therefore it was the second day of their journey before they climbed halfway up a rugged mountain and found themselves at the entrance of the Nome King's caverns.
column3: Therefore it was the second day of their journey before they climbed halfway up a rugged mountain and found themselves at the entrance of the Nome King's caverns.

column2: On their arrival, the entrance seemed free and unguarded, but Gos and Cor had been there before, and they were too wise to attempt to enter without announcing themselves,
column3: On their arrival, the entrance seemed free and unguarded, but Gos and Cor had been there before, and they were too wise to attempt to enter without announcing themselves,

column2: for the passage to the caves was full of traps and pitfalls.
column3: for the passage to the caves was full of traps and pitfalls.

column2: So King Gos stood still and shouted, and in an instant they were surrounded by a group of crooked nomes, who seemed to have sprung from the ground.
column3: So King Gos stood still and shouted, and in an instant they were surrounded by a group of crooked nomes, who seemed to have sprung from the ground.

column2: One of these had very long ears and was called The Long Eared Hearer.
column3: One of these had very long ears and was called The Long Eared Hearer.

column2: He said: I heard you coming early this morning.
column3: He said: I heard you coming early this morning.

column2: Another had eyes that looked in different directions at the same time and were curiously bright and penetrating. He could look over a hill or around a corner and was called The Lookout.
column3: Another had eyes that looked in different directions at the same time and were curiously bright and penetrating. He could look over a hill or around a corner and was called The Lookout.

column2: Said he: I saw you coming yesterday.
column3: Said he: I saw you coming yesterday.

column2: Then, said King Gos, perhaps King Kaliko is expecting us.
column3: Then, said King Gos, perhaps King Kaliko is expecting us.

column2: It is true, replied another nome, who wore a gold collar around his neck and carried a bunch of golden keys. The mighty Nome King expects you,
column3: It is true, replied another nome, who wore a gold collar around his neck and carried a bunch of golden keys. The mighty Nome King expects you,

column3: On his head was a diamond crown and in his hand he held a golden sceptre with a big jeweled ball at one end of it. This was Kaliko, the King and ruler of all the nomes.

column3: It is my desire, answered King Gos, respectfully, to place in your care two prisoners, whom you now see before you. They must be carefully guarded,

column2: They seem gentle enough, I'm sure.

column2: The prisoners, returned King Gos, are the King and Queen of Pingaree, a small island north of here.
column3: The prisoners, returned King Gos, are the King and Queen of Pingaree, a small island north of here.

column2: They are very evil people and came to our islands of Regos and Coregos to conquer them and slay our poor people.

column3: Oho! A talking goat, do you say? That certainly sounds like magic; and it also sounds like the Land of Oz, where all the animals talk, said Kaliko, with a doubtful expression.

column3: You have come here thinking to force me to give up the captives of King Gos and Queen Cor, and I wanted to convince you that my power is too mighty for anyone to oppose.

column3: Therefore, as I do not wish to hurt you, I ask you to go away peaceably and let me alone.

column3: Forgive me if I do not agree with you, King Kaliko, answered the boy.

column3: However difficult and dangerous my task may be, I cannot leave your dominions until every effort to release my parents has failed and left me completely discouraged.

column3: so I cannot entertain you properly, according to your rank;

column3: but Klik will attend you to my guest chambers and to morrow I will talk with you again.

column3: and followed their guide, Klik, down a well lighted passage and through several archways until they finally reached three nicely furnished bedchambers

column3: You are not prisoners, you know, said Klik; neither are you welcome guests, having declared your purpose to oppose our mighty King and all his hosts.

column3: But we bear you no ill will, and you are to be well fed and cared for as long as you remain in our caverns. Eat hearty, sleep tight, and pleasant dreams to you.

column2: Eggs may seem to you to be a queer weapon with which to fight, but the little girl well knew their value. The nomes are immortal; that is, they do not perish,

column2: as mortals do, unless they happen to come in contact with an egg.

column3: If an egg touches them either the outer shell or the inside of the egg the nomes lose their charm of perpetual life and thereafter are liable to die through accident or old age, just as all humans are.

column2: For this reason the sight of an egg fills a nome with terror and he will do anything to prevent an egg from touching him, even for an instant.

column2: But you must begging Your Majesty's pardon for the contradiction.
column3: But you must begging Your Majesty's pardon for the contradiction.

column3: Kitticut, cried poor Rinkitink, you must save me from being captured by these, my subjects.

column2: What! must I return to Gilgad and be forced to reign in splendid state when I much prefer to eat and sleep and sing in my own quiet way?
column3: What! must I return to Gilgad and be forced to reign in splendid state when I much prefer to eat and sleep and sing in my own quiet way?

column3: You will find it much more comfortable to reign than to die, although I fully appreciate Your Majesty's difficult position and am truly sorry for you, said Pinkerbloo.

column2: Good bye, my Prince of Pingaree; A noble King some time you'll be And long and wisely may you reign And never face a foe again!
column3: Good bye, my Prince of Pingaree; A noble King some time you'll be And long and wisely may you reign And never face a foe again!

column2: They cheered him from the shore; they cheered him from the boats; and then all the oars of the fifty boats swept downward with a single motion and dipped their blades into the purple hued waters of the Nonestic Ocean.
column3: They cheered him from the shore; they cheered him from the boats; and then all the oars of the fifty boats swept downward with a single motion and dipped their blades into the purple hued waters of the Nonestic Ocean.

column2: As the boats shot swiftly over the ripples of the sea Rinkitink turned to Prince Bobo, who had decided not to desert his former master and his present friend, and asked anxiously:
column3: As the boats shot swiftly over the ripples of the sea Rinkitink turned to Prince Bobo, who had decided not to desert his former master and his present friend, and asked anxiously:

column2: How did you like that song, Bilbil I mean Bobo?
column3: How did you like that song, Bilbil I mean Bobo?

column2: Is it a masterpiece, do you think?
column3: Is it a masterpiece, do you think?

column2: And Bobo replied with a smile: Like all your songs, dear Rinkitink, the sentiment far excels the poetry.
column3: And Bobo replied with a smile: Like all your songs, dear Rinkitink, the sentiment far excels the poetry.

column2: End of Chapter Twenty Four End of Rinkitink in Oz by L Frank Baum.
column3: End of Chapter Twenty Four End of Rinkitink in Oz by L Frank Baum.
